div.p: As it hath beene often in Action at the Black-friers.
Imprinted at London for Richard Boulan, dwelling at the ſigne of the Spred-Eagle, right ouer-againſt the great North dore of Saint Paules Church.

div.stage: Preſenter or prologue, paſſing ouer the Stage, the Bawde-gallant, with three wenches gallantly attirde, meetes him the whore-Gal|lant, the pocket-Gallant, the cheating-Gallant, kiſſe theſe three wenches and depart in a little whiſper and wanton action: now for the other the Broker-Gallant, bee ſits at home yet I warrant you, at this time of day, ſumming vp his pawnes, hactenus quaſi inductio, a little gli●pſe giuing.

sp.p: IS your pawne good and ſound ſir?
Ile pawne my life for that ſir;
Place your ſelfe there then, I will ſeeke to preferre it pre|ſently: my Maiſter is very iealous of the peſtilence; marry the po● ſits at meate and meale with him.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Lent the fift day of September to miſtreſſe Onſet vpon her gowne, Taffatie petticote with three broad ſiluer Laces, three pound fifteene ſhillings.
Lent to Iuſtice Cropſhin vpon both his Veluet Iackets, fiue pound ten ſhillings.
Lent priuately to my Lady New-cut, vpon her gilt Caſting|bottle, and her ſiluer Lye-pot, fiftie fiue ſhillings.
Sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Lent to Sir Oliuer Needy vpon his Taffatie cloake, Be|uer hat, and perfumd lether-Ierkin, 6. pound 5. ſhillings.
May it pleaſe your worſhip—

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Lent to maiſter Andrew Lucifer, vpon his flame-colourd doublet, and blew Taffity-hoſe—top the candle firrah, mee thinkes the light burnes blew-when came that ſuite in.
Tas laine aboue the yeare now?

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Fire and brimſtone, cut it out into matches, the white li|nings will ſerue for tinder.

And with little helpe ſir, they are almoſt black ynough
allready?—Sir here's an other come with a pawne;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Keepe him aſide awhile▪ and reach me hether the Bill of the laſt weeke;
T●●●●ere at hand ſir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Now ſir what's your pawne?
The ſecond part of a Gentlewomans gowne ſir, the low|er halfe I meane;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I apprehend you eaſily, the breeches of the gowne!
Very proper, for ſhee weares the doublet at home, a ghueſt that lies in my houſe ſir; ſhe lookes euery houre: for her couſine out at'h country.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh her couſine lies here a may miſtake in that? my firend of what pariſh is your pawne?
Pariſh why? Saint Clements ſir, -Ile come to you preſently,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What pariſh is your pawne my friend. Saint Brides 5. Saint Dunſt●●●s none; Saint Clements 3. 3. at Clements, away with your pawne ſir, your pariſh is infected, I will neither pur|chaſe the plague for ſix pence in the pound, and a groat Bill mony, nor venture my ſmal ſtocke into contagious pariſhes: you haue your anſwer fare-you-well, as faſt as you can ſir.
The pox arreſt you ſir at the ſuite of the Suburbs.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I welcome, welcome.
For I thinke plague ſcornes your company.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I rancke with chiefe Gallants, I loue to ſmell ſafely: lent in the vacation to maiſter Proctor vppon his Spirituall gowne, 5. angels; and vpon his Corporall doublet, 15. ſhil|lings. ſumme 3. pound 5. ſhillings.
Sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Now ſir.

div.stage: Enter his man bringing a trunke.

sp.p: Heer's one come in with a trunke of apparrell.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Whence comes it?
From Saint Martins in the field.

sp.speaker: Frip▪
sp.p: Saint Martins in the field,—Saint Mary Maudlin 2. Saint Martins none, her's an Honeſt fellow, let him appeare ſir.
You may come neere ſir,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh welcome, welcome what's your pawne ſir?
Faith a Gentlewomans whole ſuite ſir.

sp.speaker: Frie.
sp.p: Whole ſuite? tis well.
A poore kinde ſoule, troubled with a bad husband; one that puts her to her ſhifts here.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Hee puts her from her ſhifts me thinkes when ſhe is faine to pawne her clothes?
Looke you ſir, a faire Sattin gowne; new Taffaty petticote.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Stay, this petticoate has bene turnd?
Often turnd vp and down & you wil, but neuer turnd ſir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Cry you mercy indeed:
A fine white Beuer, pearle-band; 3. falls, Iha knowne her haue more in her daies.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Alaſſe and ſhe bee but a Gentlewoman of any count or charge, 3. faules are nothing, in theſe daies-Know that; tut the worlds chang'd, gentlewomans faules ſtand vpright now, no ſinne but has a Bolſter, that it may lye at eaſe: Well what do you borrow of theſe ſir?
Twelue pound and you will ſir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: How?
They were not hers for twenty.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why ſo: our pawne is euer thrice the value of our mo|ny vnles in plate and Iewells, how ſhould the moneths bee re|ſtor'd and the vſe elſe? we muſt caſt it for the twelue moneth, ſo many pounds, ſo many moneths, ſo many eighteene pences, then the vſe of theſe eighteene pences, then the want of the returne of thoſe pounds, all theſe muſt bee laid togither, which well conſidered, the valuation of the pawne had need to ſound treble: Can ſix pound pleaſure the Gentlewoman.
It may pleaſe her, but like a man of threeſcore in the Limbreſt degree.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I haue but one word more to ſay in't, twenty nobles is all and the vtmoſt that I will haxard vppon't.
ſhe muſt be content with't, the leſſe borrowed the better paid, come.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Arthur?
At hand ſir.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Tell out twenty nobles, and take her name in a Bill?
Im e ſatisfied ſir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Welcome: good Saint Martins in the field, welcome, welcome, I know no other name?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: What ſo hard at your praiers?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: A litle ſir, ſumming vp my pawnes here: what Maiſter Pri|mero? is it you ſir Gallant; and how does all the prety ſweete Ladies, thoſe plumpe, kinde, delicate bliſſes; ha? whom I kiſſe in my very thoughts: how do they Gallant?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Why Gallant? if they ſhould not doe well in my houſe, where ſhould it be done boy, haue I not a glorious Sc●tuation?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh a Gallant Receit, Violet ayre, curious garden, quaint walkes, fantaſticall Arbors, three back-doores and a Coach|gate, nay tha'rt admirably ſeated, little furniture will ſerue thee, tha'rt neuer without moueables.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I praiſe my Starres; ah the goodly virginities that haue beene cut vp in my houſe, and the goodly patrimonies that haue laine like ſops in the grauie, and when thoſe ſops were eaten, yet the meate was kept whole for another, and another, and another, for as in one pie twenty may dip their ſippits, ſo vpon one woman forty may conſume their patrimonies.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Excellent, maſter Primero?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Wel, ile pray for women while I liue, the're the profita|bleſt fooles, ile ſay that for em, a mā can keepe about his houſe the pretieſt kinde fowle, ſo tame, ſo gentle e en to ſtrangers, hands, So ſoone familiar, ſuffer to be toucht, Of thoſe they nere ſaw twice: the Doues not like em.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Moſt certaine, for thats honeſt; but I haue a ſuite to you?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And ſo haue I to you.

lg.l: That happens well,
Grant mine and ile grant yours?

sp.speaker: ●ri.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Make me perfect in that tricke that got you ſo much at Primero.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Oh for the thred tied at your partners leg: the twich?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I that twich and you calt ſo.

lg.l: That ſecret twich got me fiue hundred pound,
Ere twas firſt knowne and ſince I ha ſold it well
Fiue hundred pound laide downe ſhall not yet buy,
The ſee ſimple of my twitch I would be here with't,
Twas a bleſt inuention, I had bene a beggar many alowſie yeare
But for my twitch. It was the prettieſt twitch?
Many ouer-cheated gulls, haue fatted
Mee with the bottome of their patrimonies
Ee'n to the laſt Sope, gapte while I fed em;
who now liue by that Art that firſt vndid e'm.
But I muſt ſweare you to be ſecret, cloſe,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: As a maid, at Ten.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Had you ſworne but two yeares higher I would here h'a beleeu'd you.

lg.l: Nay I let twelue alone,
For after twelue has ſtruck, mades looke for one.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I looke for one too and a maide I thinke.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What, to come hether?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Sure ſhe followes me? a pretie fat eyde wench, with a Venus in her cheeke, did but Rayment ſmile vpon her, ſhe were Nectar for great Dons, boy and thats my ſuite to thee.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: And thats granted already: of what volume is this booke, that I may fit a couer too't?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Faith neither in folio, nor in Decimo ſexto, but in Octauo betweene both, a prety middle fizde trug.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Then I haue fitted her already: in my eye ifaith: here came a pawne in e'en now will make ſhift to ſerue her as fit, looke you ſir Gallants, Sattin, Taffety, Beuer, fall and all.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Is it new.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: New? you ſee it beares her youth as freſhly,—

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: A prety ſuite of cloathes ifaith;—but put caſe the party ſhould come to redeeme em of a ſuddaine?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Puh then your wits ſickly, haue not I the policy thinke you to ſeeme ●●treame bufie and defer em til the morrow, a|gainſt which time that pawne ſhall bee ſecretly fetcht home, and another carried out to ſupply the place.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I like thy craft well there.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: A generall courſe, oh Frippery is an vnknowne benefit ſir Gallant!

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And what muſt I giue you for the hire now ifaith.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: And for both thoſe weele fit it.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I if the deuill bee not int, make halt:

sp.speaker: Fri.

lg.l: I follow ſtraight, vaniſh thou Fog, and Sinck beneath our brightneſſe,
Abaſhed at the ſplendar of ſuch beames:
We ſcorne thee, baſſe eclipſer of our glories,
That wouldſt haue hid our ſhine from nortalls eies,
Now Gallants, I am for you, I and perhaps before you▪
You can appearce but glorious from your ſelues,
And haue your beames but drawne from your owne light,
But mine from many, many make me bright.

sp.p: Heres a dimond that ſometimes gracſt the finger of a coun|teſſe, here ſits a Ruby that neere lines bluſhing for the Party that pawnde it: here a Saphire, O prouidence and fortune! my beginning was ſo poore, I would faine forget it, and I take the only courſe, for I ſcorne to thinke ont. Sl●ue to a trencher: obſeruer of a ſaltſeller, priuy to nothing, but a cloſe-ſtoole, or ſuch vnſauory ſecret: but as I ſtriue to forget the da●es of my ſeruing, ſo I ſhall once remember the firſt ſtep of my rayſing, for hauing hardly rakte fiue marke togither, I reioyſt ſo in that ſmall ſtock, which moſt prouidently I venturde by water to Blackwall, among fiſhwiues, and in ſmall time, what by weeke|ly returne, and gainefull reſtitution it rize to a great body, be|ſide a diſh of fiſh for a preſent, that ſtately preſerude mee a ſeauen-night: nor ceaſt it there but drew on greater profit, for I was held religious by thoſe that do profeſſe like abſtinence, and was ful often ſecretly ſupplied, by charitable Catholickes, Who cenſurd me ſincerely abſtinate, when merely I for hun|ger nor ●or zeale, eate vp the fiſh, & put their almes to vſelha, ha ha; but thoſe times are runne out, and for my ſake, zealous diſſemblance has ſince far'd the worſe; —let mee ſee now, whoſe cloake ſhall I weare to day to continue change,
Oh—Arthur.
Here ſir.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p:
B●ing downe ſir Oliuer Needies Taffetv cloake. & Beuer hat, I am ſure he is faſt inough? & Andrew ●●cifers Rapier and dagger, in the knights ●ard, with the emb●ſt gitdle and han|gers, for he's in his third ſweat by this time, ſipping of the doc|to●s bottle, or picking the ninth part of a Rack of mutton drie
roaſted, with a leaſh of night-caps on his head like the popes triple crowne, and as many pillowes c●uſht to his back, with oh the needles, for he got the pox of a Se●ſter, and it prickt ſo much more naturally,—quick Arthur quick, now,

lg.l: To the deceaſt knights daughter
Whome many Gallants ſue to, I mongſt many: fo●
Since impudence gaines more reſpect then vertue,
And come them bloud which few can now deny,
who're your chiefe Gallants, then but ſuch as I.

div.stage: Enter Miſters Katherine with Fitſgraue a Gentleman.

lg.l: You do your Beauties iniury, ſweete virgin,
To looſe the time they muſt reioyce in youth:
Theres no perfection in a woman placed
But waſts it ſelfe tho it be neuer waſted,
Then iud●e your wrongs your ſelfe.
Good Maiſter Fitſgraue?
Through ſorrow ●or the knight my fathers death,
(Whoſe being was the perfections of myioye:
And crowne of my deſires,) I cannot yet,
But forcedly, on marriage fi●e my heart,
Yet heauen forbid I ſhould deiect your hopes
Conceiue not ofn eſo vncharitably,
I ſhould belie my ſoule if I ſhould ſay,
You are the man I neuer ſhould affect:
I vnderſtand you thus far, you'r a Gentleman
Whom your eſtate and vertues may command
To a farre worthier breſt, then this of mine,
O ceaſe, I dare not heare ſuch blaſphemy,
What is without you worthie, I neglect,
In you is placſt the worth that I reſpect:
Vouchſaſe vnequalld Virgin whereon I iuſtly kept,
Accept this worthleſſe fauor from your ſeruants arme, the hal|lowed beades,
The true and perfect number of my fighs.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Mine cannot equall yours, yet in exchange, accept and weare it for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Euen as my ile ra●e it?

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Heart? Fitſgraue in ſuch boſome ſingle-loues?

div.stage: Enter fiue Gallants at the farther dore.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: So cloſe, and priuate with her?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Obſerue hem, he growes proud and bould?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why was not this a generall meeting?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: By her owne conſent, Death how I could taſte his bloud?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: See, the gentlemen, at my requeſt do all preſent them-ſelues?

lg.l: Manifold bliſſes waite on her deſier,
whoſe beauty and whoſe minde ſo many honour?
I take your wiſhes thankfully? —kinde gentlemen!
all here aſſembled, ouer whoſe long ſuites,
I neare inſulted,
Not like that common ſicknes of our ſexe,
Grew proud in the aboundance of my ſuiters,
Or number of the dayes they ſu'd vnto me.
Dutifull ſorrow for my fathers death,
Not willfull coyneſſe hath my howers detaind
So long in ſilence:
Im'e left to mine owne ehoyce, ſo much the more
My care calls on me If I erre through loue,
Tis I muſt chide my ſelfe, I cannot ſhift
The fault vnto my parents, they're at reſt,
And I ſhall ſooner erre through loue, then wealth.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: That likes me well?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Hope ſtill.

lg.l: And my affections do pronounce you all▪
Worthy their pure and moſt intire deſerts,
Yet they can chooſe but one,
Nor doe I diſwade any of his hopes,
(Becauſe my heart is not yet throughly fixt,
On marriage, or the man,)
But craue the quiet reſpite of one moneth,
The moneth vnto this night, againſt which tim●,
I doe inuite you all to that election,
Which on my vnſtained faith, and Virgin promiſe,
Shall light amongſt no ſtrangers, but your ſelues:
May this content you?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Glad, and content.

lg.l: 'Tis a good time to leaue,
Till then, commend vs to your gentleſt thoughts.

div.stage: They looke ſcur●ily vpon Fitſgraue, and he vpon them. The boy in a corner, with his maiſter pocket-Gailant.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Inough.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Ough.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Hiſt, maiſter Hiſt.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Boye? how now?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Looke you ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Her Chaine of Pearle.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I ſ●eckt it away fi●ely.

lg.l: Actiue boy, thy maiſters beſt reuenew, his life & ſoule
Thou keepſt 'em both together? whip, away,
Fall back, fall belly, I muſt be maintaind,
Hope is no purchaſe, nor care I if I miſſe her, why I ranck
In this deſiegne with gallants, there's fu'l cauſe
Policie enuites me to it, 'tis not for loue, or for her ſake alone:
It keepes my ſtate ſuſpect●e●le and vnknowne.
Their lookes run through, & through me, & the ſt●●gs
Of their Snake-hiſſing whiſpers pierſt my hearing:
They're mad ſhe gracd me with one priuate minute,
Aboue their fortunes, I haue obſerud em often,
Moſt ſpightfully aſpected toward my happineſſe,
Beyond all others: but the ● use I know not,
A quiet moneth the Virgin has encloſde
Vnto her ſelfe: ſuiters ſtand without till then,
In which ſpace cunningly lle winde my ſelfe,
Into their Boſomes. I haue be-thought the ſhape,
Some credulous Scholler, eaſily infected
With faſhion▪ time, and humor. vnto ſuch
Their deepeſt thoughts, will like to wanton fiſhe●,
Play aboue water, and be all parts ſeene:
F●r ſince▪ ●●me their enuie pi●es ile ſee
Whether their liues from touch of blame ſit free.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: I ſeldome ſaw ſo few here, you ſhall haue'em ſome|times in euery corner of the houſe, with their Violls betwixt their legs, and play the ſweeteſt ſtroaks twould een filch your ſoule allmoſt out of your boſome.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Pax on't: we ſpoile our ſelues for want of theſe things at Vniuerſity?

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: You haue no ſuch natural happines, let's draw neere,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Gentlemen you are all moſt reſpectiuely welcome:

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: We are bold and inſatiate Suiters ſir to the breath of your muſicke, & the deere ſight of thoſe Ladies.

lg.l: And what our poore skill can inuite you to,
You are kindly welcome: you muſt pardon 'em Gentlemen,
Virgins and baſhfull, beſides new beginners,
Tis not a whole moneth ſince they were firſt entred.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Seauen yeare in my knowledg▪

lg.l: They bluſh at their very leſſons, they will not indure,
To heare of a Stop, a Pricke, or a Semy-quauer,

sp.speaker: 1. Curti.
sp.p: O out vpon you:

lg.l: La I tell you, youle beare me witnes Gentlemen,
If their complaints come to their parents eares,
Their words of Art, I teach 'em nought but Art.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Why tis moſt certaine.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: For all Schollers know, that Muſica eſt Ars.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O beaſtly word?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Looke to the Ladies, Gentlemen;

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Kiſſe agen?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Come an other?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: this a good Interim?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: what haue you done ſir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: why? what haue I done,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Saw you their ſtomacks queaſie, and come with ſuch groſſe meate!

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why iſt not lattin ſir,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Lattin? ●hy then let the next too't be lattin too:

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: So ynough?

sp.speaker: Goldſt▪
sp.p:
Nay I can aſſure you thus farre, I that neuer knew the
language ha eheard ſo much that Ars, is lattin for Art, and it' may wel be too, ●or ther's more art int now a daies thē euer was:

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: iſt poſſible▪ I am ſorry then I haue follow'd it ſo farr.

sp.speaker: 1. Curti.
sp.p: A Scholler call you him,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Muſicke muſt not iarre; the offence is ſatisfied, come to the Song, beg●n ſir.

div.stage: The Song, and hee keepes time, ſhowes ſeuerall humors and moods: the boy in his pocket nims away Fitsgraues Iewell here, and exit.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Not a whole moneth ſince you were entred Ladies?

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: None that ſhall ſee their cunning will beleeue it,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: It is no affliction Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I care not much yfaith, if I write downe to my father preſently, to ſend vp my ſiſter in all haſte, that I may place her here at this Muſicke ſchoole.

sp.speaker: Ne●●.
sp.p: Slid tis the foole my couſin, I would not for the value of three recreations he had ſeene me here?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: How like you your new prize;

sp.speaker: Prip.
sp.p: Pray giue me leaue, I haue not yet ſufficiently admir▪d her

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: My wits muſt not ſtand idle, Slife hee's in a ſicke trance?

lg.l: A cheat or two among theſe miſtreſſes,
Would not be ill beſtow'd, I affect none,
But for my pray ſuch are their affections,
I know it, how could drabs and cheaters liue elſe,
Then ſince the world rowles on diſſimulation,
Ile be the firſt diſſembler.
Prethy loue, comfort, choice, my onely wiſh in thee
I am confinde, deny me any thing a ſlight chaine of pearle,

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Nay an't be but ſlight—

lg.l: Being denied,
I prize it ſlight; but giuen mee by my loue,
Light ſhall not be ſo deere vnto my eye;
Mine eye vnto the body as the gift,
How haue I power to deny this to you,
That commandall my fortunes are thy ſeruants,
And thou the Miſtreſſe both of them and me.

sp.speaker: 1 Curt.
sp.p: The trueſt that ere breathd.

lg.l: To a Gentleman,
That thus ſo long and has ſo ſincerely lou'de you,
As I my ſelfe, nere was leſſe pitty ſhowne.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Why I neuer was held cruell.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: But to me.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Nor to you.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Go too, 'tas ſcarde you much,

lg.l: I'me ſorry your conce●t is ſo vnkinde,
To thinke me ſo.
When had I other argument,
I'ue often tendred you my loue and ſeruice,
And that in no meane faſhion:
Yet were you nere that requ●tefull Miſtreſſe,
That grac▪ſt me with one fauour,
Slight, not ſo much as ſuch a prety ring, pax on't,
T'as almoſt broke my heart.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Has tooke it off, Sfoot maiſter Bouſer,

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Nay where a man loues moſt, there to be ſcanted.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt,
sp.p: My Ring, come, come.

lg.l: What reckon I a Sattin gowne or two,
If ſhe were wiſe.

sp.speaker: 2, Curt.
sp.p: Life my Ring ſir, come.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Haue you the face yfaith.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Giue me my Ring.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Prethee hence, by this light you get none on't.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: How?

lg.l: I hold your fauours of more pure eſteeme,
Then to part from 'em, ●aith I doe,
How ere you thinke of me.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Puſh, pray ſir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Harke you, go too, you haue loſt much by vnkindneſſe, goe your wayes.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Sfoot.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But yet there's no time paſt, you may redeeme it.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Come, I cannot miſſe it ifaith; beſide the Gentleman that beſtowde it on me▪ ſwore to me it coſt him twenty nobles.

lg.l: Twenty nobles▪ pox of twenty nobles,
But you muſt coſt me more, you pritty villaine,
Ah you little roague.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Come come, I know y'are but in ieſt,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: In ieſt no you ſhall ſee.

lg.l: No way will get it.
As good giue it him now, and hope for ſome-what.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I ru● loue made ieſt.

lg.l: I did but trye thy faith, how faſt thou'dſt hold it,
Now I ſee a woman may venture worthy fauours to thy truſt,
and haue 'em truly kept, and I proteſt, had I drawn't from thee,
I ſhould nere ha lou'de thee, I know that.
Sfoote I was nere ſo wrongd in my life,
Thinke you I am in ieſt with you, what with my loue?
I could finde ●●ghter ſubiects you ſhall ſee,
And time will ſhew, how much you iniure me.
The Ring wer't thrice worth I freely giue,
For I know you will requite it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will I liue.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Ynough.

lg.l: Why this was well come off now,
Wheres my old Seruingman? not yet returnde,
Oh heere he peepes: now ſirrah?

sp.p: May it pleaſe your worſhip—they're done artificiallyy|faith boy.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Both the great Beakers.
Both Lad.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Iuſt the ſame ſize.
I and the markes as iuſt.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: So fall off reſpectiuely now.
My Lord deſires your worſhip of all loue.

lg.l: His Lordſhip muſt hold me excuſd till morning,
Ile not breake company to night,
Where ſup w●e Gallants?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: At Ma●-maide.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: S●p there who liſt, I haue forſworne the houſe.
Seruing. For the truth is this plot muſt take effect ●t Miter.

sp.speaker: Goold.
sp.p: Faith Ime indifferent.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: So are we Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Purſu.
sp.p: Name the place maiſter Goldſtone.

lg.l: Why the Miter in my minde,
For neate attendance, diligent boyes and, puſh, excels it faire.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, the Miter then: Boye, ſome goodneſſe toward, the Boyes whipt away.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: The Iewell, heart the Iewell.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: How now ſir? what mou'de you?

lg.l: Nothing ſir, a ſpice of poetrie, a kinde a furie,
A diſeaſe runs among Schollers.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Maſſe it made you ſtampe.

lg.l: Whoo, till make ſome ſtampe and ſtare, make a ſtrange noyſe,
Curſe ſweare, beate Tire-men, and kick players boyes,
The effects are very fearfull.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Bleſſe me from't.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Oh you need not feare it ſir—hell of this luck.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Harke, hee's at it againe.

lg.l: Some pageant plot, or ſome deuice for the Tilt-yeard:
Diſturbe him not.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: How can I gaine her loue, when I haue loſt her fauour.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: What money haſt about thee?

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Looke you ſir, I muſt be faine to pawne a faire Stone here, for ordinary expences: a pox of my tennants, I giue 'em twenty dayes after the quarter, and they cut out forty.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why you might take the forfeiture of their leaſes then.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: I know I might, but whats their courſe? the roagues comes me vp all together, with Geeſe and Capons, and petiti|ons in pigs ſhoutes, which would moue any man yfaith, were his ſtomack nere ſo great, and to ſee how pittifully the pullen will looke, it makes me after relent, and turne my anger into a quick fire to roaſt 'em—nay toucht and ſpare it not.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Tis right, well, what do's your worſhip borrow of this ſir?

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: The Stone's twenty nobles.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Nay hardly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: As I am a right Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: It comes neere it indeed: well here's fiue pound in gold vpon't.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Twill ſerue, and the Ring ſafe and ſecret,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: As a Virgins.

lg.l: I wiſh no hyer: what Gallants▪ are you conſtant,
Does the place hold?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The Miter.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Sir, in regard of our continued boldneſſe, & trouble, (which loue to your Muſick hath made vs guilty of) ſhal we in|treate your worſhips company, with theſe ſweete Ladies, your profeſt Schollers, to take part of a poore Supper with my ſelfe and theſe Gentlemen at the Miter.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Pray maiſter Primere.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: I beſeech you ſir let it be ſo.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Oh pardon me ſweet Gentlemen, the worlds apt to cen|ſure, I haue the charge of them, they'r left in truſt, they'r Virgins, and I dare not hazard their fames, the leaſt touch mars 'em, and what would their right worſhipfull parents thinke, if the report ſhould flie to them, that they were ſeene with Gentlemen in a Tauerne.

lg.l: All this may be preuented, what ſerues your coach for,
They may come coacht and maskt.
You put me too't ſir,
Yet I muſt ſay agen, I feare the Drawers,
And Vintners boyes will be familier with them,
And thinke 'em Miſtreſſes.
There are thoſe places where reſpect ſeemes ſlighter,
More cenſure is belonging to the Miter, you know that ſir?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Gentlemē you preuaile.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Weel all expect you there.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And weele not faile.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: The diuil wil nere diſſemble with them ſo, as you for thē.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come ſir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What elſe, lets go,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: How cheere you ſir?

lg.l: Faith like the Moone, more bright,
Decreaſt in body▪ but re-made in light,
Here thou ſhalt ſhare ſome of my brightneſſe with me.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: By my faith they are comfortable beames ſir.

lg.l: Come, where haue you ſpent the time now from my ſight,
Ime iealious of thy action.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Puſh I did but walke, a turne or two in the garden.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: What made you there?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Nothing but cropt a flower.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: Some womans honor I beleeue.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Foh, is this a womans honor.

lg.l: Much about one?
When both are pluckt their ſweetneſſe is ſoone gon.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Prethe be true to me.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: When did I faile.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Yet I am euer doubtfull, that your ſinne.

lg.l: I do account the world but as my ſpoile, to adorne thee,
My loue is artificiall to all others,
But purity to thee,—doſt thou want gold?
Here take this chaine of pearle, ſupply thy ſelfe,
Be thou but conſtant, firme and iuſt to mee,
Rich heires ſhall want, ere want come neere to thee.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Vpon thy lip I ſeale ſincerity.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Was this your vowe to mee?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Pox, whats a kiſſe to be quite rid of her, ſhee's ſued ſo long I was aſhamde of her, twas but her cheeke I kiſt neither, to ſaue her longing.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Tis not a kiſſe I weigh.

lg.l: Had you weighed this,
T'ad lackt aboue fiue ounces of a true one:
No kiſſe that ere weighed lighter.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Tis thy loue that I ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: My loue, why by this,—what ſhall I ſweare by?

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Sweare by this iewell, keepe thy oth, keepe that▪

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: By this iewell then, no creature can bee perfect in my loue, but thy▪ deere ſelfe.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: I reſt.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, lets laugh at em ſweete ſoule.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: I, they may laugh at me, I was a nouice, and beleiude your oths,

lg.l: Why what do you thinke of me, make I no difference,
Turne ſeauen yeares proſtitution, and ſeauen daies,
Why you're but in the waine of a maide yet:
You wronge my health in thinking I loue them,
Do not I know their populous imperfections.
Why they cannot liue till Eaſter, let em ſhew
The faireſt ſide to'th world like hundreds more, whoſe clothes
E'en ſtand vpright in ſiluer, when theire bodie,
Are ready to drop through em, ſuch there be,
They may deceiue the world, they nere ſhall mee.
Forgiue my doubts, and for ſome ſatiſfaction were this ●ing,
From which I vow de nere, but to the, to part.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: With which thou euer bindſt me to thy heart.

lg.l: My pocket pickt, this was no bro●he●-houſe,
A muſick ſchoole; damnation has fine ſhapes,
I paide inoug for'th ſong, I haue loſt a iewell
To me more pretious then their ſoules to them,
That gaue conſent to filch it, ile hunt hard:
Waſt time and money, trace and wheele about,
But I wil find theſe ſecret miſchiefes out-how now, whats he:
Oh a ſeruant to my loue, being thus diſguizde,
Ile learne ſome newes, now ſir; you belong to me.

sp.p: I Do ſir, but I cannot ſtay to ſay, ſo, nay good ſir detaine me not I am going in al haſt to enquire or lay waite for a chain of pearle nimd out of her pocket the fift of Nouember, a diſ|mall day.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Ha a chaine of pearle ſaiſt thou.
A chaine of pearle ſir, which one Maiſter Fitſgraue a gen|tleman and a ſuiter faſtned vpon her as a pleadge of his loue.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Ha?

lg.l: Vrge me no more I haue no more to ſay,
Your friend Ieroni●o Bedlam.
Thou 'rt a mad fellow indeed, ſome comfort yet,
Thats hers is miſſing too, I feele my ſoule at much more eaſe: both ſtolne.
When griefes haue partners they are better borne.
Oh the parting of vs twaine, Enter Wbore Gal.
Hath cauſde me mickle paine, and I ſhall nere be married,
Vntill I ſee my muggle againe.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Hiſt?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: The nimble gentleman, in the cleſtiall ſtockins.

lg.l: Has the beſt ſmock fortune, to be belou'd of women?
Valle loo lo lille lo lilo, vallee loo lee lo lillo.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Vallee loo lo lillee lilo, Vallee loo le lo lil'o.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Ah ſweete gentleman, he keepes it vp ſtately.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Well held ifaith ſir—maſſe and now I remember too, I thinke you nere ſaw my little banquiting, box aboue, ſince I al|terd it.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Why haue you alterd that?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Oh diuinely ſir: the pictuers are all new run ouer againe.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Fie.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: For what had the painter done thinke you, drew mee, Venus naked, which is the grace of a mans Roome you know, & when he had done, drew a number of Oken-leaues before her, had not lawne beene a hundred times ſofter, made a better ſhew, and beene more gentlewoman like?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: More ladie-like, a great dea'e.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Come, you ſhall ſee how tis alterd now? I do not thinke but you'le like her.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Where be your liueries?
They attend without.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Go, call the Coach! Gentlemen, you haue exceld in kindneſſe as we in bouldneſſe.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: So you thinke amiſſe ſir?

lg.l: Kind Ladies we commit you to ſweete dreames,
Our ſelues vnto the fortune of the dice, dice ho?

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: You reſt firme mine.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: E'en al my ſoule to thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: You keepe your vowes.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Why do I breathe, or ſee?

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: Is your loue conſtant.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I to none but thes● now gon, I, now I loue nor them nor thee, ſlife, I ſhould be cloide, ſhould I loue one in three.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Oh heres maiſter Bowſer now.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Saue you ſweete Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Sweete maiſter Bowſer? welcome?

sp.speaker: Purſu.
sp.p: When come theſe dice.

sp.speaker: Purſu.
sp.p: Yet anon, anon ſir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Haſt thou ſhowne art in em.
You ſhall be iudge ſir, here be the Tauerne Beakers, And here peepe out the fine Alchimy knaues, looking like, wel ſir, moſt of our Gallants, that ſeeme what they are not.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Peace villaine, am not I in preſence.
Why that puts me in minde of the ieſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Goldſt.
sp.p: Agen, you quarter her.
Nay, compare 'em, and ſpare 'em not.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The bigneſſe of the bore, iuſt the ſame ſize, The markes, no difference: away, put money in thy pocket, and offer to draw in vpon the leaſt occaſion.
I am no babe ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hiſt.
Whats the matter now?

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Giue me a paire of falſe Dice, ere you goe.
Pax on't, you're ſo troubleſome too, you cannot remem|ber a thing before, if I ſtay a little longer, I ſhall be ſtaid anon.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Here be Dice for your worſhips.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Oh come, come.

lg.l: The Vintner himſelfe,
Ilo ſhift away theſe beakets by a ſlight.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Maiſter Goldſtone?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How now you coniuring raskall?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Bleſſe your good worſhip, you're in humors me thinks.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Humors: ſay that agen.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I ſaid no ſuch wond ſir,—would I had my beakers out on's fingers.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Whats thy name Vintner?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Iack and pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Turne Knight like thy companions, ſcoundrell, liue vpō vſury, weare thy gilt ſpurs at thy girdle for feare of ſlubbering.

lg.l: O no, I hope I ſhall haue more grace then ſo ſir:
Pray let me helpe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Cannot I puſh 'em together without your helpe?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: O I beſeech your worſhip, they're the two ſtandards of my houſe.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Standards, there lie your Standards.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Good your worſhip; I am glad they are out of his fin|gers, my wife ſhall lock 'em vp preſently, they ſhall ſee no ſunne this twelue-months day for this trick.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Let me come to the ſight of your Standards agen.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Your worſhip ſhall pardon mee, now you ſhall not ſee em in haſt I warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I do not deſire't; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Why maiſter Goldſtone?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am for you Gallants—Maiſter Boxeer cry you mercy ſir, why ſupt you from vs?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Faith ſir, I met with a couple of my fellow pupils at V|niuerſitie, & ſo we renew'd our acquaintance & ſupt together.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Fie, thats none of the neweſt faſhion, I muſt tell you that maiſter Bouſer, you muſt neuer take acquaintance of any ath' Vniuerſity, when you are at London, nor any of London when you're at Vniuerſity you muſt be more forgetfull yfaith, euery place miniſters his acquaintance aboundantly.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: He tels you true ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I warrant you here's a Gentleman will nere commit ſuch an abſurdity.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Who I, no, 'tis well knowne, if I be diſpoſde, Ile forget any man in a ſeauen-night, and yet looke him in the face: nay let him ride but ten mile from mee, and come home againe, it ſhall be at my choiſe whether Ile remember him or no, I haue tryed that.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: This is ſtrange ſir.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: 'Tis as a man giues his minde too 't ſir: and now you bring me in; I remember 'twas once my fortune to be coozned of all my clothes, and with my clothes my money; a poore Shepheard pitting me, tooke me in, and relieu de me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Twas kindly done of him ifaith,

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Nay you ſhall ſee now, 'twas his fortune likewiſe not long after, to come to mee in much diſtreſſe ifaith, and with weeping eyes, and do you thinke I remembred him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You could not chooſe.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: By my troth not ●, I ſorgot him quite, and neuer remem|bred him to this houre.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And yet knew who he was.

lg.l: As well as I know you ifaith—
'Tis a gift giu'n to ſome aboue others.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To fooles and knaues they neuer miſſe on't.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: Do's any make ſuch a wonder at this; why alas tis nothing to forget others; what ſay you to thoſe that forget themſelues?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay then to Dice: come ſet me Gallants, ſet.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p:
I, fall too 't Gentlemen. I ſhall heere ſome newes from ſome of you anon: I haue th'art to know which looſe and nere looke on; Ile bee ready with all the worſt money I can finde
about me, Arthur!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Here ſir.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Stand ready.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Feare not me ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Theſe are mine ſir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Here's a waſht Angell, it ſhall away: Here's Miſtreſſe Roſe-noble has loſt her maiden-head, crackt in the Ring, ſhoe's good enough for gaimſters, and to paſſe from man to man: for gold preſents at Dice your harlot, in one houre wone and loſt thrice, euery man has a fling at her.

sp.speaker: ●ay.
sp.p: Agen pax of theſe dice

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: Tis ill to curſe the dead ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſ▪
sp.p: Mew, where ſhould I wiſh the pox, but among bones.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: He tels you right ſir.

lg.l: I nere haue any luck at theſe odde hands,
None here to make vs fixe—why Maiſter Frip.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I am very well here I thanke you ſir, I had rather be tel|ling my money my ſelfe, then haue others count it for mee; tis the ſcuruieſt muſick in the world me thinkes, to heare my mony gingle in other mens pockets, I neuer had any mind toot ifaith.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Slud play ſix or play foure, Ile play no more.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sfoot you ſee, there's none here to draw in.
Rather then you ſhould be deſtitute gentlemen, ile play my ten pound, if my maiſters worſhip will giue me leaue.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: He ſhall, he ſhall.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pray excuſe me Gentlemen: ●ſoot how now goodmā Raſcall, what? becauſe you ſeru'd my Grand-father when hee went Ambaſſador, & got ſome ten pound by'th hand, has that put ſuch ſpirit in you, to offer to draw in among Gentlemen of worſhip, knaue.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Pray ſir, lets intreate ſo much for once.

lg.l: 'Tis a vſuall grace ifaith ſir,
Yo'ue many gentlemen will play with their men.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I and with their Maides to yfaith.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Good ſir giue him leaue.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, come, and you be weary on't, I pray draw nere ſir.
Not ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Come foole, feare nothing, I warrant toe, h'as giuen thee leaue, ſtand here by me, come now, ſet round Gentlemen, ſet,

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: How the poore fellow ſhakes: throw luſtily man.
At all gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Well ſaid ifaith.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: The're all mine.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: By my troth I am glad the fellow has ſuch luck, ●t will encourage him well.
At my maiſters worſhip alone.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Now ſit ſlaue?
At my maiſters worſhip alone.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: So, ſawcy raskall.
At my maiſters worſhip alone.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: You're a roague and will be euer be one?
By my troth Gentlemen at all agen for once.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Take em to the● boy, take em to thee, thou'rt worthy of em ifaith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Gentlemen faith I am angry with you, goe and ſuborne my knaue againe me here; to make him proud & peremptory.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Troth thats but your conceite ſir, the fellowes an ho|neſt fellow and knowes his duty, I dare ſweare for him.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Heart, I am ſick already.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Whether goes Maiſter—

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Play on, ile take my turne ſi●?—boye?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Maiſter.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Piſt?—a ſupply, cary't cloſely my little fooker,—how much—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Three pound ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Good boye,—take out another leſſon? how now gen|tlemen?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Deuills int did you ere ſee ſuch a hand?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: I ſet you theſe three angells.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My maiſter may ſet hie? —for all his ſtakes are drawne out of other mens pockets.
As I ſaid gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Dues Ace.
At all your right worſhipfull worſhips.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Death and vengance!

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Hell, darkeneſſe,

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Hold ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Maiſter Goldſtone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hinder me not ſweete gentlemen—you raskall—I baniſh thee the boord.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Yfaith but you ſhall not ſir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Touch a Die and thou darſt, come you in with your low|zie ten pound, you ſlaue among gentlemen of worſhippe, and win thirty at a hand.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Why will you kick agen luck ſir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: As long as the poore fellow ventures the loſſe of his owne money, who can be offended at his fortunes.
I haue a Maiſter here? many a Gentleman would bee glad to ſee his man come forward aha.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Prey be perſwaded ſir:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: 'Slife, here's none cuts my throate in play but he I haue obſerude it, an vnluckly ſlaue tis.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Me thinkes his lucks good inough ſir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Vpon condition Gentlemen that I may euer bar him frō the boord hereafter I am content to winck at him.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Faith, vſe your owne pleaſure hereafter, has won our mony now! come to'th table ſir your maſter's friends with you.
Pray Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: The fiends int I thinke, I left a faire chaine of pearle at my lodging too, like an aſſe and nere remembred it; that would ha bin a good pawn now, ſpeake what do you lend vpon theſe Maiſter Frip? I care not much if you take my Beuer hat too, for I perceiue tis darke inough already, & it dos but troble me here.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Very well ſir why now I can lend you 3. pound ſir—

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Prethe do't quickly then?▪

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: There tis in ſix angels.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Very compendiouſly.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Here Arthur, runne away with theſe preſently, ile enter em into'th ſhop-booke to morrow. Item one gilt hatcht rapier and dagger, with a faire imbrodered girdle, and hangers, with which came alſo a Beuer hat, with a correſpondent band.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Puſh, ifaith ſir your to blame, you haue ſnibd the poore fellow too much, hee can ſcarce ſpeake, hee cleaues his words with ſobbing.
Haff haff, haff, haff at al Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Ah roague, ile make you know your ſelfe.
At the fayreſt.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Out ifaith—two Aces.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: I am glad of that, come pay me al theſe good-man cloake|bag:

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Why are you the fayreſt ſir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: You neede not doubt of that ſir—fiue. angells you Scoundrell.
Fie ath theſe Dice, not one hand to night,—there they go Gentlemen at al ifaith.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Pay all with 2. treas and a quater.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Al curſes follow em, pay your ſelues withall, ile pawne my ſelfe to't, but ile ſee a hand to night, not once hold in? here Maiſter Frip, lend me your hand, quick, quick, So.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What do you borrow of this doublet now?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Nere ſaw the world three daies.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Go too, in regard your a continuall cuſtomer, ile vſe you well, and pleaſure you with fiue angels vpon't.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Let me not ſtand too long ith cold for them:

lg.l: Had euer country gentleman ſuch fortune?
All ſwoopt away ide, neede repaire to'th Brokers,

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: If you be in that minde ſir there ſits a Gentleman will furniſh you vpon any pawne, as well as the publickſt broker of em all:

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Say you ſo ſir, there's comfort in that ifaith.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Item, vpon his oringe tawny ſattin doublet, fiue angells,

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: But by your leaue ſir? next comes the breeches,—.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh I haue tongue fit for any thing—

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Sauing your taile ſir? tis giuen me to vnderſtand that you are a Gentleman ith hundred, and deale in the premiſes aforeſaide.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Maiſter Bungler, Maiſter Bungler, y'are mightily miſ|tooke, I am content to do a gentleman a pleaſure for once, ſo his pawne be neate and ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why what ſay you to my Grandfathers ſeale ring here

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I marry ſir, this is ſomewhat like.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Nay view it well, an antient armes, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Whats this ſir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: The great codpeice with nothing int.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: The word about it, partur iunt montes.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Whats that I pray ſir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: You promiſe to mount vs.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: And belike he was not ſo good as his word.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: So it ſhould ſeeme by the Story, for ſo our names came to be Bunglers▪

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: A lamentable hearing that ſo great a houſe ſhould ſhrink and fall to ruine.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Two quaters and yet looſe it heart, boy? ▪ifaith? what iſt?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Fiue pound ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: By my troth this boy goes forward well, yee ſhall ●ee him come to his preferment ith' end!

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Why how now, whoſe that gentlemen, a barge-man?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I neuer haue any luck Gallants, till my doublets off, Ime not halfe nimble inough, at this old finquanter driuel|beard:

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Your worſhip muſt pay me al theſe ſir?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: There, and feaſt the deuill with em.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Hel gnawe theſe dice.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What do you giue ouer Gallants.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Iſt not time.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I proteſt, I haue but one angell left to guid me home to my lodging.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: How much thinkſt?

sp.speaker: Fulk.
sp.p: Some foureſcore angells, ſir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Peace, weele ioyne powers anon, and ſee how ſtrong w● are in the whole number, maſſe, yon guilt Goblet ſtands ſo full in mine eye, the whorſon tempts me, it comes like cheeſe after a great feaſt, to diſgeſt the reſt, he wil hardly ſcape mee ifaith I ſee that by him already; back for a parting blow now,▪boy?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Anon anon ſir:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Fetch a penneworth of ſoft wax to ſeale letters.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I will ſir?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Nay had not I ſtrange caſting, thrice togither, 2. qua|ters and a dews.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Why was not I as often haunted with two treas, and a quater:

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Ther's wax for your worſhip—anon, anon, ſir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Screene me a little you whorſon old croſſe biter.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Why whats the buſines? fil chiton h●b Goblet.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: And what has maiſter Bowſer loſt?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Faith not very deepely ſir, inough for a ſcholler, ſome halfe a ſcore royals.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Sfoot I haue loſt as many with ſpurs at their heeles.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Come Gallants ſhall we ſtumble:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Whats a clock.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Heres none ont Dick, the Goblets carried downe.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Nay tis vpon the point of three, boy, Drawer, whats to be done ſirs?

sp.speaker: Uint.
sp.p: All's paid, and your worſhips are welcome, Onely there's a Goblet miſſing Gentlemen, and cannot bee found about houſe.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: How a Goblet:

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: What manner a one▪

sp.speaker: Uint.
sp.p: A guilt Goblet ſir, of an indifferent ſize.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sfoote I ſaw ſuch a one lately.

sp.speaker: Uint.
sp.p: It cannot be found now ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Came there no ſtrangers here?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: No ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: This a meruelous matter, that a Goblet ſhould bee gone, and none but wee in the roome, the loſſe is meere all, heere as we are; keepe the doore Vintner.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: No I beſeech your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: By my troth Vintner weele haue a priuy ſearch for this; What? we are not all one womans children.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I beſeech yee Gentlemen, haue not that conceit of me, that I ſuſpect your worſhips.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tut, you are an Aſſe; do you know euery mans nature: There's a Broker ith' company.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Slife you haue not ſtole the Goblet, boy, haue you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Not I ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: I was afraide,—tis a good cauſe ifaith, let each man ſearch his fellow, weele begin with you.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I ſhall ſaue ſome body a labour Gentlemen, for Ime halfe ſearcht already.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: I thought the Goblet had hung heere ifaith—none heere, nor heere.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Seeke about flower,—What was the Goblet worth Vintne.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Three pound ten ſh●lings ſir no more.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pox on't Gentlemen, tis but Angels a peece, it ſhall be a brace of mine, rather then I would haue our reputations brea|thed vpon by all commers, for you muſt thinke theile talke ont in all companies; ſuch a night, in ſuch a company, ſuch a Gob|let, Sfoote it may growe to a gangrene in our credits and bee incurable.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Faith I am content.

sp.speaker: Frip,
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: There's my Angell too.

sp.speaker: Gol▪
sp.p:
So, and mine, Ile tell thee what, the miſſing of this goblet
has diſmaide the Gentlemen much.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I am ſory for that ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yet they ſend thee this comfort by me, if they ſee thee but reſt ſatisfied, and depart away contented, which will ap|peare in thy countenance; not three times thrice the worth of the Goblet ſhall hang betweene them and thee, both in their continuall cuſtome, and all their acquaintances.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I thanke their worſhips all▪I am ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Say it againe: do you heare Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I thanke your worſhips all I am ſatiſfied.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why la, was not this better then hazarding our repu|tations vpon trifles, and in ſuch publicke as a Tauerne, ſuch a queſtionable place.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Faith it was well thought on. Nay keepe your way Gen|tlemē: I haue ſworne maiſter Bowcer, I will bee laſt ifaith▪ Raſcall the goblet.

sp.speaker: Fulk.
sp.p: Where ſir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Peepe yon ſir vnder.

sp.speaker: Fulk.
sp.p: Heere ſir.

div.head: ACTVS. 4.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: My husband is rode from home, make us delay', I know if your will bee as free as your horſe, you will ſee '●ee yet ●re dinner: From Kingston this eleuenth of Nouvember▪ Ha? theſe womē are ſuch creatures ſuch importunate ſweet ſoules: theile ſca●ſe giue a mā leaue to be ready, that's their onely fault ifaith, if they be once ſet vpon a thing, why there's no remoouing of em, till their pritty wils be fulfild—O pitty thy poore oppreſſed client here ſweete Cupid, that has ſcarce ſixe houres vacation in a moneth, his cauſes hang in ſo many Courts, yet neuer ſuffer my French aduerſary, nor his big ſwolne confederates to ouer|throw me,▪Who without mercy would my bloud carouſe, And lay me in priſon in a Doctors houſe:
Thy clemencie great Cupid: peace, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Sir Gallant, well encountred.

sp.speaker: Talb.
sp.p: I both ſalute, and take my leaue together.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Why whether ſo faſt ſir▪

lg.l: Excuſe me pray, lme in a little haſt,
My horſe waites for me.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: What ſome iourney toward?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: A light one ifaith ſir.

lg.l: I am ſorry that my buſineſſe ſo commands me,
I cannot ride with you; but I make no queſtion,
You haue company inough.
Alaſſe not any—nor do I deſire it,
Why 'tis but to Kingſton yonder.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: O cry you mercy ſir,

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Scape but one reach, there's little danger thether.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: True a little of Come-parke.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: You'ue namde the place ſir, that's all I feare ifaith,

lg.l: Farewell ſweere maiſter Taylebee,
This fell out happily; Ile call this purchaſe mine, before I greete him,
Een where his feare lyes moſt, there will I meete him: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Walke my horſe behinde yon thicket, giue a word, if you diſcrie.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I haue all perfect ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: So, he cannot now belong: What with my boyes dex|terity at Ordinaries, and my Geldings celerity ouer hedge and ditch, but we make pritty ſhift to rub out, a Gallant, for I haue learnt theſe principles.

lg.l: Stoope thou toth' world, 'twill on thy boſome tread,
It ſtoopes to thee, if thou aduance thy head:
The minde beeing farre more excellent then fate,
Tis fit our minde then be aboue our ſtate;
Why ſhould I write my catremitics in my brow,
To make them loath me, that reſpect me now,
If euery man were in his courſes knowne;
Legs that now honor him, might ſpurne him downe.
To conclude, nothing ſeemes as it is but honeſty, & that makes it ſo little regarded amongſt vs.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Eela, ha, ho.

sp.speaker: Puſn.
sp.p: The Boye: hee's hard at hand, Ile croſſe him ſudden|ly: and here he comes; ſtand.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Deliuer your purſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I fear'd none but this place ifaith, nay when my minde giues me a thing once.

lg.l: Quick, quick ſir, quick.
I muſt diſpatch three robberies yet ere night.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I'me glad you haue ſuch good doings by my troth ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Youle fare neuer a whit the better for your flattery I warrant you ſir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I ſpeake ſincearly, 'tis pitty ſuch a proper-parted gen|tleman ſhould want; nor ſhall you, as long as I haue't about me, nay ſearch and ſpare not: there's a purſe in my left pocket as I take it, with fifteene pound in gold in't, and there's a faire chaine of pearle in the other: nay I'e deale truly with you; it greeues me yfaith when I ſee ſuch goodly men in diſtreſſe, Ile rather want it my ſelfe then they ſhould go with-out it.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: And that shewes a good nature ſir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Nay tho I ſay it, I haue beene alwaies accounted a man of a good nature, I might haue hangd my ſelfe ere this time els▪ Pray vſe me like a gentleman, take all, but iniury not my body.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: You muſt pardon me ſir, I muſt a little play the Vſurer, and binde you, for mine owne ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Alaſſe ther's no conſcience in that ſir, ſhall I enter into bond, and pay money too.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Tut, I muſt not be betrayd.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Here me but what I ſay ſir, I do proteſt I would not be he that ſhould betray a man, to be Prince of the world.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Maſſe that's the diuill, I thanke you heartily, for hee's cal'd prince ath' world.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: You take me ſtill at worſt.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Sweare on this ſword then, to ſet ſpurs to your horſe, not to looke back, to giue no markes to any paſſenger.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Markes, why I thinke you haue left me nere a peny ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: I meane no markes of any.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I vnderſtand you ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Sweare then.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ifaith I do ſir:

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ime gon ſir, by my troth of a fierce theefe he ſeemes to be a very honeſt Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Purſ.

lg.l: Why this was well aduentured, trim a Gallant:
Now with a courteous and long thuſting eye,

sp.p: Let me behold my purchaſe, & try the ſoundues of my bones with laughter, how? is n●t this the chaine o● pearle I gaue to that periurde ha●lat, tis, Sfoot tis, the very chaine, oh damned miſtreſſe, ha; and this the purſe, which not fiue daies before I ſene▪ her fild with faire ſpur-royalls—heart; the very gold?—ſlife is this no robbery, how many othes flew toward heauen,

lg.l: Which nere came halfe way thether; but like fire drakes,
Mounted a little, gaue a cracke, and fell;
Fainde othes bound vp to ſinke more deepe to hell.
What folded papers this? death—tis her hand.

sp.p: Maiſter Taylbee, you know with what affection I loue you, You do:
I count the world but as my pray to maintaine you, The more diſſembling queane you I muſt tell you,
I haue ſent you an embroderd purſe here with fifty faire ſpur|royalls int—A pox on you for your labour wench: And I deſire you of all loues to keepe that chaine of pearle from Maiſter Purſnets ſight—
He cannot ſtrumpet, I behold it now, vnto thy ſecret torture:

p.hi: So fare thee well, but be conſtant and want nothing.

sp.p: As long as I ha't ifayth? me thinkes it ſhould haue gon ſo,—well; what a horrible age do we liue in, that a man cannot haue a queane to himſelfe let him but turne his back the beſt of her is chipt away like a Court loafe, that whē a man comes himſelf, has nothing but bumbaſt; & theſe are 2. ſimple chippings here, do's my boy pick, & I ſteale, to enrich my ſelfe, to keepe her, to maintaine him: why this is right the ſequence of the world,—A. L. maintaines her, ſhe maintaines a Knight, he maintaines a Whore, ſhee maintaines a captaine. So in like manner, the poc|ket keepes my boye, hee keepes me, I keepe her, ſhee keepes him, it runs like quick-ſiluer, from one to another; Sfoote I per|ceiue I haue beene the chiefe vpholder of this Gallant all this while; it appeares true, we that pay deereſt for our paſture are e|uer likely worſe-uſde, Sfoot he has a Nag can run for nothing, has his choiſe, nay and gets by the running of him;—oh fine world ſtrange deuills, and prety damnable affections.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Lela ha, ho?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: There boy, agen, what newes there?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Maiſter, piſt, maſter?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: How now boye.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I haue diſcride a prize.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Another lad?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The gull, the ſcholler?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Maiſter Bowſer:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I, comes a long this way:

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Without company.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As ſure, as he is your owne.

lg.l: Back to thy place boye,
I haue the luck to day, to rob in ſafety:
Two pretious cowards, whiſt: I heare him—ſtand

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: You lie, I came forth to goe.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Deliuer your purſe.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Tis better in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: How now, at diſputations, ſignior foole.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: I'ue ſo much logick to con●ute a knaue, a thiefe, a rogue-

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Hold, hold, ſir, and you be a gentleman hold, let mee riſe.

lg.l: Heart tis the curtizy of his ſcarf vn●askt him to me,
Aboue the lip by chance, ile counterfit,
Light, becauſe I am a ſcholler, you thinke belike that ſchollers haue no mettal in em, but you ſhal finde,—I haue not don with you couſin.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: As you're a Gentleman:

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: As you're a roague?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Keepe on vpon your way ſir:

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: You bad me ſtand?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: I haue beene once downe for that:

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: And then deliuer?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Deliuer mee from you ſir—oh pax on't, has wounded me Eela, ha, ho my horſe, my horſe boye:

lg.l: Haue you your boy ſo ready: oh thou world,
How art thou muffled in deceitfull fonnes:
There's ſuch a miſt of theſe, and ſtill hath beene,
The brightneſſe of true Gentry is ſcarce ſeene:
This iourney was moſt happily aſſignde,
I haue found him droſſe both in his meanes and minde: what
papers this he dropt? ile looke on't as I goe.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: A gull call you him, let me alwaies ſet vpon wiſemen, theyle be afread of their liues, they haue a feeling of their in|niquities, and knowes what tis to die with fighting▪ sfoote this gull laies on without feare, or wit, how deepe's it ſayſt thou boye?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: By my faith three inches ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: La, this was long of you, you roague:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Of me ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Forgiue me deere boy, my wound akte, and I grewe angry, there's hope of life boy, is there not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Puh, my life for yours.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: A comfortable boye in mans extreames! I was nere ſo afread in my life but the foole would haue ſeene my face, hee had mee at ſuch aduantage, hee might haue commanded my Sca●f●, Iſcapt well there tad choakt mee; my reputation had beene paſt recouery, yet liue I vnſuſpected, and ſtil fit for Gal|lants choice ſocieties—but here I vowe, if ere I ſee this Bow|ſer when hee cannot ſee mee, either in by-lane, priuiledge place, Court, Alley, or come bekinde him when hees ſtanding, or take him when heereeles from a Tauerne late, piſſing a|gaine a Cundit, Wall, or Gate, when hee's in ſuch a plight and cleere from me, ile do that I am aſhamde to ſpeake till then.
Nay reade forward, I haue found 3. of your Gallants, like your bewitching ſhame meerely ſophiſticall, there's your Bawde-Gallant, your pocket-Gallant, & your Whore-Gallant.
Maiſter Taylbee.
Thats he
I count the world but as my prey, to maintaine you?
Thats iuſt the phraze and ſtil of em all, to him: they meete altogither in one effect, and it may well hold too, for they all iumpe vpon one cauſe, ſubands lechery.

lg.l: What ſhapes can flattery take, let me entreate you,
Both in the virgins right, and our good hopes
Since your houres are ſo fortunate, to proceede.

sp.p: Why he's baſe that faires, vntil he crowne his deed.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: See that diſſembling deuill, that periurde ſtrumpet.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Welcome my ſoules beſt wiſh,—oh out alaſle▪ thy arme bound in a ſcarfe, I ſhall ſowne inſtantly,

lg.l: Heart and ile fetch you agen in the ſame tune,
O my vnmatched loue, if any ſparke of life remaine,
Looke vp, my comfort, my delight, my—

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: O good, o good?

lg.l: The organ of her voice is tunde agen,
Theres hope in women, when their ſpeech returnes▪
See like the Moone after a black ecclipſe,
She by degrees recouers her pure light:
How cheeres my loue?
As one new wah't out of a deadly trance,
The fit ſcarce quiet.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Twas terrible for the time, Ide much ado to fetch you.

lg.l: Shrew your fingers,
How came my comfort wounded, ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Faith in a fray laſt night.

lg.l: In a fray? will you looſe your bloud ſo vainely,
Many a poore creature lacks it, tell me how?
What was the quarrell?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Loath to tell you that.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Loath to tell me.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Yet twas my cauſe of comming.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: Why then, muſt not I know it:

lg.l: Since you vrge it, you ſhall,
Y'are a ſtrumpet.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: O newes abroad ſir?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Say you ſo.

sp.speaker: 1 Curt.
sp.p: Why you knew that the firſt night you lay with me.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Nay not to me, onely but to the world.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Speake within compaſſe man.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Faith you know none, you ſaile without.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: I haue the better skill then.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: At my firſt ſtep into a Tauerne-roome, to ſpie that chaine of pearle wound on a ſtrangers arme you begd of me.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: How, you miſlooke it ſure.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: By heauen the very ſelfe ſame chaine▪

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: O cry you mercy, tis true, ide forgot it, tis S. Georges day to morrow, I lent it to my couzin onely to grace his arme before his m●ſ●is.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Notable cunning.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: And is this all now ifaith.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Not, I durſt goe further.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Why, let me neuer poſſeſſe your loue, if you ſee not that againe a Thurſday morning, I tak't vnkindly yfaith you ſhould fall out with me for ſuch atrifle.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Better and better.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Come, a kiſſe and friends.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: By this hand Ile ſpoile your atme and you will not.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: More for this then the Diuell.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yee, at your booke ſo hard.

lg.l: Againſt my will, are you there Signior Logick,
A pox of you ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why how now, what has fate ſent vs here, in the name of Venus goddeſſe of Cypreſſe.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: A Free-booters pinck ſir, three or foure inches deepe.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No more, thats conſcionable yfaith.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Troth Ime ſory for't, pray how came ir ſir?

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Faith by a paltry fray, in Colman-ſtreete.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Coome-parke he would ſay.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: No leſſe then three at once ſir, made a Triangle with their Swords and Daggers, and all oppoſing me.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: And amongſt thoſe three, onely one hurt you ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Ex for ex.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Troth and Ile tell you what luck I had too, ſince I par|ted from you laſt.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: What I pray?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: The day you offered to ride with mee, I wiſh now Ide had your company, Sfoote I was ſet vpon in Coome-parke by three too.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Bah.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Robd by this light of as much gold and Iewels, as I va|lued at forty pound,

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Sure Saturne is in the fifth houſe.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I know not that, hee may be in the ſixt and he will for me, I am ſure they were in my pocket whereſoeuer they were: but Ile nere refuſe a Gentlemans company agen when 'tis of|fered me, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I muſt remember you, 'tis Miter-night Ladies.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Maſſe 'tis indeed, Friday to day, Ide quite forgot, when a womans buſie, how the time runs away.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Oh y'aue betraid vs both.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: I vnderſtand you not.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Y'aue let him ſee, the chaine of Pearle I gaue you.

lg.l: Who him: will you beleeue me,
By this hand he neuer ſaw it.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Vpon a ſtrangers arme he ſwore to me,

lg.l: Maſſe that may be, for the truh is ifaith,
I was robd on't `at Coome-parke.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Twas that betraid it,

lg.l: I would had ſtaide him,
He was no ſtranger, he was a theefe yfaith,
For theeues will be no ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: How ſhall I excuſe it?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Nay I haue you faſt inough boy, you roague.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Good ſir, I beſeech you ſir, let me go.

sp.speaker: Bung▪
sp.p: A pick-pocket, nay you ſhall to Newgate luck you: is this your Boy ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: How now boy? a monſter? thy arme linde faſt in an others pocket, where learnt you that manners; what compa|ny haue you kept alate, that you are ſo tranſformd into a roage, that ſhape I know n●t, beleeue me ſir I much wonder at the al|teration of this boy, where he ſhould get this nature: as good a childe to ſee to, and as vertuous, hee has his Creed by heart, reads me his chapter duly euery night; hee will not miſſe you one tittle in the nine commandements.

sp.speaker: Bungl.
sp.p: Theres ten of em.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: I feare he skips ore one; thou ſhalt not ſteale.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Maſſe like enough.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Elſe grace and memory, would quite abaſh the boy. Thou graceleſſe impe, ah thou prodigious child, begot at ſome ec ipſe, degenerate rogue. Shame to thy friends, and to thy mai|ſter eke: how far digreſſing from the noble minde of thy braue Anceſters that lie in Marble, with their coate a●●ors ore em.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Had he ſuch friends?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: The boy is well diſcended, though he be a rogue and has no feeling ont, yet for my ſake, & for my reputations ſeeke not the bloud of the boy, his neere allyed to many men of wor|ſhip now yet liuing, a fine old man to his father, it would kill his heart yfaith, heed away like a Cryſom.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Alaſſe good gentleman?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Ah ſhameles villaine, complainſt thou? doſt thou want?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, no, no, no.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Art not well clad, thy hunger well reſiſted.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, yes,

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: But thou ſhalt ſtraight to Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sweet maiſter.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Liue vpon bread and water, and chap choake.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I beſeech your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Come Ile be his ſuerty for once:

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe me indeed ſir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: He will mend, a may proue an honeſt man for all this, I know gallant Gentlemen now, that haue done as much as this comes too in their youth.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Say you ſo ſir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: And as for Bridewell, that will but make him worſe, a will learne more knauery there in one weeke, then will furniſh him and his heires for a hundreth yeare.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Deliuer the boy.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Nay I tell you true Sir, ther's none goes in there a queane, but ſhe comes out an arrant whore I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: The boy comes not there for a million.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: No you had better forgiue him by ten parts.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: True, but a muſt not know it comes from me, downe a your knees you rogue, and thanke this gentleman has got your pardon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O I thanke your worſhip:

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: A pox on you for a rogue, you put me to my ſette ſpeech onee a quarter:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay gentlemen you quite forget your houre, ●ead maiſter Bowſer
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Gold; and Curtiſan.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Let me go you'r a diſſembler

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: How.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Did not you promiſe me a new gowne?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Did I not? yes faith did I, and thou ſhalt haue it, goe firrah runne for a Tayler preſently.
Let me ſee for the coulour now; Orange tawny, Peach colour, what ſayſt to a Watchet Sattin?

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: O tis the onely colour I affect.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: A very orient colour, ant pleaſe your worſhips, I made a gowne ont for a Gentlewoman tother day, and it does paſſing well vpon her.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A Watchet Sattin gowne.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: There your worſhip left ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Laid about Tayler.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: Very good Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: With foure faire Laces.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: That will be coſtly ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How you rogue coſtly, out ath'houſe, you ſlip-ſhood, ſhamlegd, browne-thred, penny-skeand raſcall.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Nay my ſweete loue.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hang him rogue, he's but a Botcher neither, come Ile ſend thee a fellow worth a hundred of this, if the ſlaue were cleane inough.

div.stage: In the midſt of the muſick enter one bringing in a ſui●e of Satin, knocks at Taylbees doore, enter his man.

sp.p: Who knocks.
A Chriſtian: pray is not this maiſter Taylbees lodging, I was directed het her.
Yes, this is my maiſters lodging.
Cry you mercy ſir. Is he yet ſtirring.
Hee's awake, but not yet ſtirring, for he plaide away halfe his clothes laſt night
My miſtreſſe commends her ſecrets vnto him, and preſents him by me with a new Sattin ſuite here.
Maſſe that comes happily.
And ſhe hopes the faſhion will content him.
Ther's no doubt to be had of that ſir—your miſtreſſe name I pray? y'are much pretiouſly welcome.
I thanke you vncommonly ſir.
The ſuite ſhall be accepted I warrant you ſir.
Thats all my Miſtreſſe deſires ſir.
Fare you well ſir.
Fare you well ſir.
This will make my maiſter leape out of the bed for ioy, and dance Wigmois galliard in his ſhift about the chamber?

div.stage: The Muſicke plaies on a while, then en|ter; Taylb●e his man after truſſing him.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Came this ſuit from miſtris Cle●ueland?

sp.speaker: Iacke.
sp.p: She ſent it ſecretly ſir.

sp.speaker: Taylb
sp.p: A pritty requitefull ſquall, I like that woman, that can remember a good turne 3 moneths a'er the date, it ſhewes both a good memory, and a very feeling ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: This came fortunately ſir, after all your ill lucke laſt night.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: I'de beaſtly caſting Iacke.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Oh abom nable ſir, you had the ſcuruieſt hand—the old Seruingman ſwoopt vp all;

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: I am glad the fortune lighted vpon the poore fellow by my troth, tmade his maiſter nad?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Did you marke that ſir, ● warrant hee has the doggedſt maiſter of any poore fellow vnder the dog-ſigne, Ide rather ſerue your worſhip, Ile ſay that behinde vour backe ●ir, for no|thing, as indeed I haue no ſtanding wages at all, your worſhip knowes.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Oh but your vailes Iacke your vailes conſidered, when you run too and fro betweene me and miſtreſſes.

sp.speaker: Ia
sp.p: I muſt confeſſe my vailes are able to keepe an honeſt man go I where I lift.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: go to then Iacke.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: But thoſe vailes ſtand with the ſtate of your body ſir as long as you hold vp your head, if that droop once, farewell you, farewell I, farewell all, and droop it will, though all the caudles in Europe ſhould put to their helping hands toot; tis ee'n as vncertaine as playing now vu now downe, for if the Bill riſe to aboue thirty, heer's no place for players, ſo if your yeares riſe to aboue 〈…〉ty, ther's no roome for old lechers.

sp.speaker: Tabl.
sp.p: and thats the rea on all roomes are taken vp for young Temp'ers?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: y'are in the right ſir?

sp.speaker: Tal●.
sp.p: pize ont I pawnd a good beuer hat to maiſter Frip laſt night Iacke,
I feele the want of it now, —harke whoſe that knockes;
I● maiſter Taylbee ſtirring?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Whats your pleaſure with him, he walks hereith hall.
Giue ●our worſhip good morrow,

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Welcome honeſt lad;
A letter from my miſtr●ſſe.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Whoſe th● miſtreſſe?
Miſtreſſe 〈…〉 blocke.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Miſtreſſ new-blocke my ſincere loue how do's ſhe?
Faith onely ●●n the wait of your ſight.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: A●aſſe ●eere ſweet, Iu'e had ſuch buiſines, I proteſt I nere ſtood ſtill ſince I ſaw her.
She has ſent your worſhip a Beuer hat heere, with a band beſt in faſhion.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: How ſhall I requite this deere ſoule?
Tit not a thing fit for mee to tell you ſir, for I haue three yeares to ſerue yet: your worſhip knowes how I warrant you;

sp.speaker: Tal●.
sp.p: I know the drift of her letter, and for the Beuer, ſay, I accept it highly.
O● ſhee will be a proud woman of that ſir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And harke thee tell thy miſtreſſe as lm'e a Gentleman, Ile diſpatch her out of hand, the firſt thing I do a my credit, canſt thou remember theſe words now?
Yes ſiras you are a Gentleman you'le diſpatch her out of hand the firſt thing you do

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ia my credit.
Oh of your credit, I thought not of that fir.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Remember that good boy?
Feare it not now fir.

sp.speaker: Tayl
sp.p: I dreamt to nighe Iacke, I ſhould haue a ſecret ſupply out a'th Citty

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Your dreame craules out partly well ſir,—what newes there now?
I haue an arrant no maiſter Taylbee—

sp.speaker: Iacke.
sp.p: Yonder walks my maiſt●r;

Miſtres Tiffany commends her to your worſhip and h'as ſent you your ten pound in gold backe gaine, and ſayes ſhee cannot furniſh you of the ſame Lawne you deſire, till after
all hollantide—

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Thanke her ſhe would let me vnderſtand ſo much? ha, ha,—this wench wil liue, why this was ſent like a worke wo|man now, the reſt are borchers to her, faith I commend her cunning, ſhees a foole, that makes her ſeruant fellowe to her heart, it robs her of reſpect, dams vp all duty, keepes her in awe e'en of the ſlaue ſhee keepes.

lg.l: This takes a wiſe courſe I commend her more,
Sends back the gold, I neuer ſawe before:
Well women are my beſt friends ifaith,
Takes lands giue me good legs:
Firme back white hand black eye, browne haire,
And ad but to theſe fiue a comly ſtature,
Let others liue by art and I by nature.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Maiſter Bowſer Maiſtr Bowſer, ha, ha, ho, maiſter Bowſer.

sp.speaker: Fuſg
sp.p: Holla:

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What not out of thy kennel, Maiſter Bowſer.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Maiſter Goldſtone, your an early Gallant ſir?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: A faire cloake yonder ifaith,—by my troth a bed Mai|ſter Bowſer, you remember your promiſe well ore night.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Why whats a clock ſir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Do you aske that now, why the chimes are ſpent at Saint Brides.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Tis a Gentlemans houre, ſaith Maiſter Goldſtone ile bee ready in a trice.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Away theres no truſt to you:

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Faith ile come inſtantly?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay chuſe whether you will or no, by my troth your cloake ſhall goe before you—
