sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Nay Maiſter Goldſtore I ha ſworke—do you heare ſir:

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Away, away, faith Ime angry with you, pox, a bed now Ime aſhamde of it.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p:
Foote my cloake, my cloake Maiſter Goldſtone, ſlife what meant you by this ſir you'le bring it back agen, I hope, no not yet, by my troth I care very little for ſuch kinde of ieſting, me thinkes this familiarity now extends a little too far, vnleſſe it be a new faſhion come forth this morning▪ ſecreetly yeſter|day twould haue ſhowne vnmannerly, and ſawcily; I ſcarce
know yet what to thinke on't, well there's no great profit in ſtanding in my ſhirt, ile on with my cloathes, has bound mee to follow the ſuite, my cloakes a ſtranger hee was made but yeſterday, & I do not loue to truſt him alone in company.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What may I coniecture of this Goldſtone? hee has not onely pawnde to me this cloake, but the verie Diamond and Saphire, which I beſtowde vpon my new loue at Maiſter Pri|meroes houſe; the cloakes new and comes fitly, to do me great grace at a wedding this morning, to which I was ſolemnly enuited. I can continue change more thē the proudeſt Gallant of em all; yet neuer beſtowe pennie of my ſelfe, my pawnes do ſo kindly furniſh mee: but the ſight of theſe iewells is able to cloy me, di● I nor preſerue my ſtomack the better for the wedding dinner, a guift could neuer haue come in a more pati|ent h●ure, nor to be better diſgeſted; is ſhe prou'd falſe,—but ile not fiet to day no▪ chafe my bloud.

sp.speaker: Purſu.
sp.p: Ha, yonder goes Bowſer, the place is fit:—boy ſtand with my horſe at Corner, I owe you for a Pinck 3. inches deepe ſir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: On—o—o;

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Take that in part of payment; for Coome-parke:

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: On—o—o?

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: How now, whoſe this? sfoote one of our Gallants, knockt downe like a Calfe, is there ſuch a plauge of em here at London, they begun to knock em ath head already:

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh Maiſter Bowſer, prayrend me your hand ſir; I am ſlaine:

lg.l: Slaine and aliue? oh cruell execution?
What man ſo ſauage-ſpirited durſt preſume,
To ſtrike downe ●attin on two taffeties cut:
O● li●e his hand againſt a Beuet hat.
Some toague that owes me money, and had no other meanes
To a wedding dinner: I muſt be d'eſt myſelf me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Fit'g.
sp.p: How why this my cloake, life how came my cloake hether?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: welſaid maiſter Bowcer, firſt the Deuice, a fair purſe wide open, the mouth downeward, the word Alli●nis ecce crumenis?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Whats that prithee?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Your bounty powres it ſelfe forth to all men.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: And ſo it does ifaith? that's all my fault, bountifull?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Maiſter Goldſtone heers yours ſir, 3. ſiluer Dice, the word, Fratrem{que} Patrem{que}?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: And whats that?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Fortune of my ſide?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Welſaid little Bowcer yfaith?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: What ſay you to me ſir?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: For the deuice A Candle in a corner; the word, Con|ſumptio, Victus:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: The meaning of that ſir?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: My light is yet in darknes, till ●in●oy her, right ſir?

sp.speaker: Pri
sp.p: Now mine ſir?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: The Deuice an vnuallued pearle hid in a Caue.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Ah ha ſirs?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: The word, Occultes vendit honores;

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Very-good I warrant,

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: A black mans a pearle in a faire Ladyes eye,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I ſaid twas ſome ſuch thing;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: My turne muſt needs come now; am I fitted Maiſter Bowcer?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Truſt to me, your deuice here is a Cuckow ſitting on a tree,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: The Welſh Lidger, good.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: The word, En Anis ex A●ib●s.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I marry ſir.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Why do you know what 'tis ſir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: No by my troth not yet ſir▪

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Oh, I keepe one tune, I ●ecant not.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I me like the Cuckow in that indeed, where I loue I hold.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Did I not promiſe you I would fit you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: They re all very well done ifaith, and very Schollerlike, tho I ſay't before thy face little Bowcer, but I would not haue thee proud ont now: come if this be performde well.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Who the Boy, he has performd deeper matters then this.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: I a pox on him, I thinke was in my pocket now, and truth were knowne.

sp.speaker: Bungl.
sp.p: I caught him once in mine.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Suppoſe the ſhields are preſented, then you begin boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I repreſenting Mercury, am a Pick-pocket, and haue his part at my fingers ends, Page I am to that great and ſecret theefe, magno illo et Secret● Latroni.

sp.speaker: Bungl.
sp.p: There you make your honor ſir▪

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: At Latroni.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: You haue it ſir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Latroni, thats mine.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: He confeſles the Theefe's his.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Remember boy, you point Latroni to me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To you Maiſter, proceede▪

sp.speaker: Ftiſ.
sp.p: Theſe foure are his companions, the one a notable chea|ter, that will cooſen his owne father.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Maiſter Goldſtone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Let mee alone maiſter Boucer, I can take mine owne turne.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Why.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: The ſecond an notorious letcher maintained by harlots cuius virtus conſumptio corpus.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Thats I maiſter Bowcer.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: There you remember your honor ſir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ille leno pretioſiſſi●●s, Virgineos ob lucrum vendens honores.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: It ſounds very well yfaith.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Poſtremus ill●, quamuis apparatuſplendidus, is no other|wiſe but a Broker, theſe fethers are not his owne, ſed anis ex Auibus; all which to bee nothing but truth, will appeare by the euent.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Ifaith here's all now Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Short and pithy.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: A good boy yfaith and a pregnant.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: I dare put truſt in the Boy ſir; forget not firrah at any ▪hand to point that ſame Latroni to me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I warrant you maiſter.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen the time beckons vs away.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: I, furniſh Gentlemen, furniſh.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Harke one word maiſter Boucer, what's the ſame La|troni, I haue a good minde to that word ifaith.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Is it yours ſir,? Maiſter Goldſtone pawnde it to me this morning freſh and ●a●●ing▪ and borrowed ſiue pound vpon't.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: How, pawnde i●? pray let me neare out this ſtory, come, and ile lend you to the next barbers-ſurgeons;—pawnde my cloake?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: How now Mar●aduke whats the wager;

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Nay my care is at end ſir, now I am come to the ſight of you? my miſtris your couzin entreates you to take part of a dinner with her at home at her houſe, and bring what Gentleman you pleaſe to accompany you.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Thanke my ſweet couze, ile munch with her ſay.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ile tell her ſo.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Marmaduke—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Will there be any ſtock-fiſh thinkſt thou?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Tell my couze I'ue a great appetite to ſtock-fiſh ifaith—Maiſter Goldſtone ile intreate you to bee the gentleman that ſhall accompany me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No●? me ſir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: You ſir.

sp.speaker: Bung
sp.p: By my troth concluded, what ſtate beares thy couze ●irrah?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Oh a fine Merchants wife,—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Or rather a Merchants fine wife—

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Truſt me and thats the ●roperer phraze here at Lon|don, and tis as abſurd too, to call him ●ine Merchant, for be|ing at ſea, a man knowes not what pickle he is in.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Why true—

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Yet my couze will be ſerude in plate I can tell you, ſhe has her ſiluer lug● and her guilt Tankards.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Fie.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Nay you ſhall ſee a houſe dreſt v● ifaith, you muſt not thinke ●o tread ath ground when you come there.—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: No, how ther●?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Why vpon paths made of fig-frailes, & white blankets cut out in ſteakes.

sp.speaker: Go
sp.p: Away—I haue thought of a deuice, where ſhal we meete an houre hence.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: In Powles.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Agreed.

lg.l: The Broker-Gallant, and the Cheating-Gallant,
Now I haue found 'em all, I ſo reioyce,
That the redeeming of my cloake I wey not:
I haue ſpyed him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pax here's Boucer.

sp.speaker: Fitſ
sp.p: Maiſter Goldſtone, my cloake, come wher's my cloake ſir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh y'are a ſure Gentleman; eſpecially if a man ſtand in need of you, he may bee ſlaine in a morning to breakfaſt, ere you vouchſafe to peepe out of your lodging.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No leſſe then foure Gallants, as Ime a gentleman, drew all vpon me at once, and oppoſde mee ſo ſpightfully, that I not onely loſt your cloake ith' fray.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: C●mes it in there?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But my tic●e Hangers, ſirrah, I thinke thou haſt ſeene e●●.

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Neuer i●a●h ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Thoſe with the two Vnicornes, all wrought in Pearle and gold pex on't it frets me ten times more then the loſſe of the platty cloake; prethee and thou lou'ſt me ſpeake no more on●t, it brings the Vnicornes into my minde, and thou wouldſt not thinke how the conceit greeues me: I will not do thee that diſgrace ifaith, to offer thee any ſatisfaction, for in my ſoule I thinke thou ſcornſt it thou bearſt that minde in my conſcience▪ I haue alwaies ſaid ſo of thee; fare thee well, when ſhall I ſee thee at my chamber, when?

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: Euery day ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I haue ●ine toyes to ſhow thee.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: You win my heart then:

The Diuill ſcarce knew what a portion hee gaue his children, when he allowde 'em large impudence to liue vpon, & ſo turnd em into th'world, ſurely he gaue away the third part of the ri|ches of his kingdome, reuenues are but fooles too't; the filed tongue and the vndaunted fore-head,

lg.l: Are mighty patrimonies, wealthier then thoſe
The Citty-Sire, or the Court-father leaues,
In theſe behold it, riches oft like flaues
Reuolt, they beare their fore-heads to their graues,
What ſooneſt graſps aduancement, me ● great ſuites
Trips downe rich widowes, gaines repute and name,
Makes way where ere it comes, bewitches all
Thou impudence, the minion of our dayes
On whoſe pale cheekes fauor and fortune playes!
Call you theſe your fiue Gallants, truſt me they'r rare fellowes
They liue on nothing; many cannot liue on ſomething,
Heere they may take example;—Suſpectleſſe virgin!
How eaſie had thy Goodneſſe bene beguilde
Now onely reſts, that as to me they'r knowne,
So to the world their baſe Arts may be ſhowne.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Art ſure thou ſaw'ſt him receiu't boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Forty pound in gold as Im'e a gentleman borne,

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Thy father gaue the Rams-head boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No you'r deceiu'd my mother gaue that ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: whats thy mothers, is thy fathers;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Im'e ſorry it holds in the Rams-head, ſee heere he walkes, I was ſure hee came into Powles, the gold had bene yours maiſter long ere this, but that he weares both his hands in his pockets:

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: How vnfortunately is my purpoſe ſeated, what the de|uill ſhould come in his minde to keepe in his hands ſo long, the biting but of a paultry louſe would do me great kindnes now, I knew not how to requite ●t, will no raſcall creature aſſiſt mee, ſtay, what i● I did impudently ſalute 'em out, good, boy be redy boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: vpon the leaſt aduantage ſir?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: You'r moſt deuoutly met in Powles ſir?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.p: So are you, but I ſcarce remember you ſir.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Oh I cry you mercy ſir, I pray pardō me I feare I haue tendred an offence ſir, troth I tooke you at the firſt for one maiſter Dumplin a Norfolke gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.p: Ther's no harme done yet ſir?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: I hope hee is there by this time, how now boy, haſt it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No by troth haue I not, this labours loſt, 'tis in the right pocket, and he kept that hand in ſure enough.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Vnpractizd Gallant, ſalute me but with one hand, like a counterfeit ſouldier, O times and manners? are wee growne beaſts, doe wee ſalute by halfes, are not our limbes at leiſure, wheres comely nurture, the Italian kiſſe, or the French cringe, with the Polonian waſte: are all forgot, then miſery followes—Surely fate forbad it, had hee imploide but his right hand, Ide had it:—It muſt be an euerlaſting deuiſe I thinke, that procures both his hands out at once: do you walke ſir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: No I ſtay a little for a Gentlemans comming too.

sp.speaker: Piam.
sp.p: Farewell then ſir, I haue forty pound in gold about me, which I muſt preſently ſend downe into the countrey.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Fare you well ſir: I wonder Maiſter Goldſtone ſpares my company ſo long, 'tis now about the nauill of the day, vpon the belly of noone.

div.stage: Enter Goldſt. and his man diſguiſde both.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: See where he walkes, be ſure you let off at a twinckling now.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: When did I miſſe you,—your worſhip has forgot, you promiſt Miſtreſſe Newcut your cozen, to dine with her this day.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Maſſe that was well remembred.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I am bold to ſalute you ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Is Miſtreſſe New-cut your coozen ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, ſhee's a coozen of mine ſir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Then I am a coozen of yours, by the Siſters ſide.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Let me ſalute you then, I ſhall be glad of your farther acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I am a bidden gueſt here too.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Indeed ſir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Faith inuited this morning.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Your good company, s●all be kindly imbrac'd ſir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I walke a turne or two here for a Gentleman, but I thinke heele either ouer-take me, or be before me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tis very likely ſir; there ſirrah, go to dinner, & about two waite for mee?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Nay let him come betweene two and three coozen, for we loue to ſit long at dinner ith' Citty.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come ſweete coozen.

lg.l: Nay coozen, keepe your way coozen,
Good coozen I will not yfaith coozen.

sp.speaker: New,
sp.p: Why how now ſirtah, vpon twelue of the clock, & not the cloth laide yet—muſt we needs keepe Exchange time ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am about it forſooth.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Y'are about it forſooth; y'are ſtill about many things, but you nere do one well, I am an Aſſe to keep thee inth' houſe now my husbands at ſea, thou haſt no audacity with thee, a fooliſh dreaming lad, fitter to be in the garret, thē in any place elſe, no grace, nor manly behauiour; when didſt thou euer come to mee, but with thy head hanging downe, oh decheerefull prentize, vncomfortable ſeruant: pray heauen the Gull my coo|zen has ſo much wit left, as to bring maiſter Taylbee along with him; my comfort, my delight, for that was the chiefeſt cauſe I did inuite him, I bad him bring what Gentlemen he pleazd to accompany him, as farre as I durſt goe, why may hee not then make choiſe of maiſter Taylbee, had hee my wit or feeling hee would doo't.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Wher's my ſweet coozen here, dos ſhe lack any gueſſe?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Euer ſuch gueſſe as you, y'are welcome coozen.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am rude Lady.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Y'are moſt welcome ſir.

lg.l: There will be a gallant here anon cooze,
Hee promiſt faithfully.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Who iſt maiſter Taylbee?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Maiſter Taylbee, no maiſter Goldſtone.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Maiſt. Goldſtone; I could thinke well of that Goldſtone, wert not for one vilde trick he has.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Whats that Lady?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: In ieſt, he will pawne his punc es for ſuppers.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Thats a vilde part in him ifaith, & he were my brother.

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: Pray gentlemen ſit a while, your dinner ſhall come pre|ſently.

lg.l: Yee miſtreſſe New-cut, at firſt giue me a trip,
A cloſe bite alwayes askes a ſecret nip.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: My coozen here is a very kind natur'd ſoule ifaith, in her humor.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Puh you know her not ſo wel as I cooze, I haue obſeru'd her in all her humors you nere ſaw her a little waſpiſh I thinke.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I haue Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Puh, then yea nere ſawe prety humor in your life, I ca● bring her into't when I liſt.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Would you could ifaith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Would I could? by my troth and I were ſure thou couldſt keepe thy countenance couze, what a prety ieſt haue I thought vpon already to entertaine time before dinner.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Preche couze what iſt, I loue a ieſt a life ifaith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Ah but I am iealious you will not keepe your counte|nance ifaith.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Why yea ſhall ſee a prety ſtory of a humor.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Faith ile try you for once, you know my couzin will wonder when ſhe comes in to ſee the cloath layd and nere a ſalt vpon the boord.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: Thats true ifaith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Now will I ſtand a while out of ſight with it, and giue her humour play a little.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Couze doſt thou loue mee, and thou wilt euer doe any thing for me, do't.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Marry I build vpon you countenance.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why doſt thou thinke Ime an aſſe couze?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: I would be loath to vndertake it elſe, for if you ſhould burſt out preſently, couze the ieſt would be ſpoild.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why do not I know that, away, ſtand cloſe, ſo, ſo mum couzen? a merry companion ifaith, here will be good ſport a|non,—whiſt ſhe comes?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I make you ſtray long for a bad dinner, here couzen, if Maiſter Goldſtone were come, the meates e'en ready.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: Some great buſines detaines him couzin, but heele not be long now?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why how now, cuds my life,—

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Was euer miſtris ſo plaugd with a ſhetle-headed ſer|uant—why Marmaduke.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I come forſooth:

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Able to ſhame me from generation to generation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Did you call forſooth?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Come hether forſooth—did you lay this cloth?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes forſooth:

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Do you vſe to lay a cloth without a ſalt, a ſalt, a ſalt, a ſalt, a ſalt, a ſalt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How many ſalts would you haue, Ime ſure I ſet the beſt ith houſe vpon the boore.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: How? couzen:—ſings—couzen, couzen, did call couze.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Did you ſee a ſalt vpon the boord when you came in.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Puh.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Come, come, I thought as much, beſhrew your ſin|gers, where iſt now?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Your couzen yonder.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why the mans mad.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Couzen, hiſt couzen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What ſay you.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Puh, I call not you, I call my couzen, come forth with th' ſalt couzen: ha, how, nobody: why wa● not he that came in e'en now your couzen?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My couzen: O my bell ſalt, O my great bell ſalt.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: The tenor bell ſalt; oh here comes Maiſter Goldſtone now couzen, he may tell vs ſome newes on him. Did you not meete a fellow about doore, with a great ſiluer ſalt vnder his arme.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No ſure, I met none ſuch.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Pardon me ſir, I forgot all this while to bid you wel|come. I ſhall loth this roome for euer. Take hence the cloth you vnlucky maple-fac'd raſcall, come you ſhall dine in my chamber ſir.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: No better place lady.

sp.speaker: Pya.
sp.p: No leſſe then forty pound in faire gold at one lift, the next ſhall ſowne, and ſowne agen till the diuill fetch him ere I ſet hand to him, heart, nothing vexes mee ſo much▪ but that I payde the Goldſmith for the change too not an houre before, had I let it alone in the chaine of ſiluer as it was at firſt, it might haue giuen mee ſome notice at his departure, sfoote I could fight with a win-mill now, ſure twas ſome vnlucky vil|laine, why ſhould he come and ſalute mee wrongfully too miſ|take me at noone day, now I thinke ont in cold bloud? it could not be but an induction to ſome villanous purpoſe, well, I ſhal meete him—

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: This forty pound came fortunately to redeeme my chaine of pearle from morgage, I would not care how often I ſowned to haue ſuch a good cawdle to comfort me, gold and pearle is very reſtoratiue.—

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: See yonders the roague I ſuſpect for fowle play, ile walke muffled by him, offer ſome offence or cauſe of a quarrel, only to try his temper, if he be a coward, he's the likelier to be a roague, an infallible note.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: What a pox aile you ſir, would I had beene aware of you.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Sir, ſpeake you to me?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Not I ſir, pray keepe on your way I haue nothing to ſay to you.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Y'are a raskall.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: You may, ſay your pleaſure ſir,—but I hope I goe not like a raskall.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Are you▪ faine to flie to your cloathes, becauſe ya●e Gallant, why theres no raskall, like your Calla●t raskall be|leeue that.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: You haue tooke mee at ſuch an houre, faith you may call me e'en what you pleaſe, nothing wil mooue me.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: No, ile make ſomewhat n ooue you? drawe? I ſuſpected you were a roague, & you haue purſt it vp wel with a coward?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Who my Patron.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Keepe out you raskall.

lg.l: The geſt that did me the kindneſſe in Powles,
Hold as you are a gentleman, youle giue me breath ſir.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Are you there with mee, a vengeance ſtop you, you haue found breath inough to run away from mee I will neuer meete this ſlaue hereafter in a morning but I will breath my ſelfe vpon him, ſince I can haue no other ſatisfaction, hee ſhail ſaue me that forty pound in fence-ſchoole.

sp.speaker: Gold.

lg.l: When things are clenly carried, ſigne of iudgement,
I was the welcomſt Gallant to her aliue,
After the ſalt was ſtolne; then a good dinner,
A fine prouoking meale which drewe on apace,
The pleaſure of a day-bed, and I had it:
This here one ring can witneſſe, when I parted,
Who but ſeewte Maiſter Goldſtone, I left her in that trance.
What cannot wit ſo it be impudent
Deuiſe and compaſſe? I would faine know that fellow now,
That would ſuſpect me but for what I am.

sp.p: He liues not,; 'Tis all in the conueyance, what? Thou lookſt not like a begger, what makſt thou on the groūd, I haue a hand to help thee vp, a faire chaine of pearle, ſurely a marchants wife giues lucky bandſell; they that finde pearle may wear't at a cheape rate, mary my Lady dropt it from her arme for a deuice to toale me to her bed, Iu'e ſeene as great a matter—who be theſe? Ile be to crafty for you, oh mounſier Primero, Signior Fr●, is it you gallants.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Sweet maiſter Goldſtone?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: euery bawd exceeds mee in fortune: maiſter Primero was rob'd of a Carkanet vpon monday laſt▪ laid the goldſmiths and found it. I h'a laid goldſmits Ieweller, Burniſher Broker, and the deuill and all I thinke, yet could neuer ſo much as here of that chaine of pearle, he was a notable theefe, hee workes cloſe; peace, who be theſe, ha●let mee ſee, by this light there it 'tis backe leaſt they ſee thee; a happy minute, Goldſtone what an age do we breath in, who, that ſaw him now would thinke hee were maintaind by purſes: ſo, who, that meets me, would th●nke I were maintaind by wenches, as far as I can ſee tis all one caſe, and holds both in one Court, wee are both maintaind by the common roade way? Keep thou thine owne heart, thou liu'ſt vnſuſpected, I leeſe you againe now.

lg.l: But I pray you tell me,
met you no Gentlewomen by the way you came?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Not any what ſhould they be?

lg.l: Nay I do but aſke,
Becauſe a Gentlewomans gloue was found,
Neere to the place I met you?

sp.speaker: Primero.
sp.p: Faith we ſaw none ſir.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: good officers, vpon ſuſpition of fellony.

sp.speaker: Cunſt.
sp.p: Very good ſir
What call you the theefs name you do ſuſpect?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Maiſter Iuſtinian Goldstone.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Remember, maiſter Iuſtice Goldſtone, a terrible world the whilſt, my Maiſters.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Looke you that's he; vpon him officers.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I ſee him not yet, which is he ſir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Why that.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: He a theefe ſir, who that Gentleman ith' Satt in?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Een hee.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Farewell ſir, y'are a merry Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: As you will anſwer it officers, Ile beare you out, Ile be your warrant.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Nay and you ſay ſo, what's his name then.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Iuſtinian Goldſtone.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Maiſter Iuſtinian Goldſtone, wee apprehend you ſir vpon ſuſpition of fellonie.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Mee.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: You ſir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I charge you in the Kings name gentlemen to aſſiſt vs.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Maiſter Taylbee?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: The ſame man ſir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Life whats the newes?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha you forgot Come-parke?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come-parke? no, tis in Kingſtone way.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I beleeue youle finde it ſo.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I not deny it.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Beare witneſſe has confeſt.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What haue I confeſt, paire of cockſcombes indubitable?

lg.l: I was robd finely of this chaine of Pearle there,
And forty faire Spur-Royals.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Did I rob you?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: There where I finde my goods I may ſuſpect ſir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I dreamt this would be his end.

lg.l: See how I am wrongd Gentlemen:
As I haue a ſoule, I found this chaine of pearle,
Not three yeards from this place, iuſt when I met you.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yet the law's ſuch, if he but ſweare 'tis you, y'are gon.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pox ont, that ere I ſaw't.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Can you but ſweare 'tis he, do but that, and you tickle him yfaith?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Nay and it come once to ſwearing let me alone:

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Say and hold, hee call'd my Iewells counterfet, and ſo cheated the poore wench of 'em:

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Come bring him away, come?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: T will call my ſtate in queſtion!

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: I thinke what's got by theft doth neuer proſper, Now loſt my chaine of pearle—come maiſter Goldſtone, lets go this mine yfaith,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The chaine of pearle?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: By my trothit's mine;

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: By my troth much good do't you ſir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Im'e glad in my ſoule ſie—Gnawes,

sp.speaker: Cunſt.
sp.p: Deliuer your weapons,

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cunſt.
sp.p: You're apprehended vpon ſupition of fellony?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Fellony? whats that'

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Was it you yfaith, ſir all this while, that did me that kindnes to eaſe both my pockets at Coom-parke:

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: I ſi●? pray gentlemen draw neere, lets talke among our ſelues, ſtand a part Scoundrell;—muſt euery gentleman be vp braided in publike that flies out now and then vpon neceſſi|ty, to be Theames for pedlers and weauers? this ſhou●d not bee, twas neuer ſeene among the Romaines; nor read we of it in the time of Brute▪ are wee more Brutiſh now? did I liſt to blab, do not I know your courſe of liſe maiſter Taylbee to bee as baſe as the baſeſt, maintaind by mee, by him by all of vs, and a ſecond hand from miſtreſſes, Iu'e their letters heere to ſhow?
Why ſhould you be ſo violent to ſtrip naked

Anothers Reputation, to the world knowing your owne ſo le|prous, Beſide this ●nai●ie of pearle and thoſe ſpur-royals came to you fa ſe y for ſhe broke her faith, and made her ſoule a ſtrumpet with her body, when ſhe ſent thoſe; they were euer iuſtly mine? Pray what moues you ſir, why ſhould yo● ſhake your head, you'r cleere, ſure I ſhould know you ſir, pray are not you ſome|times a pandar, & oftner a bawd ſir, haue I neuer Sin'd in your ban-quetting boxes, your bowers and towers? you ſlaue, that keeps fornication vpon the tops of trees, the very Birds can|not in gender in quiet for you, why rogue, that goes in good clothes made out of wenches caſt gownes.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Nothing goes ſo neere my heart as that?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Do you ſhake your ſlaues nodle?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And heer's a raskall lookt aſway too, (ſauing the pre, ſeace of maiſter Goldſtone;) a filthy-ſlymy-louſie-nitticall bro|ker, prickt vp in pawnes from the hat-band to the ſhooſtring|a neceſſary hooke to hang gentlemens ſuites ont it'h Aire, leaſt they ſhould grow muſty with long lying? which his pawnes ſeldome are guilty off, a fellow of ſeuerall ſents and Seeamea; French, Duch, Italian, Engliſh, and therefore his lice muſt needs be mungrells. why Bill mony?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am ſorry to heere this among you, y'aue all deceiu'd me, truly I tooke you for other Spirits, you muſt pardon mee hence-forward, I haue a reputation to looke to, I muſt bee no more ſeene in your companies;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, nay, maiſter Golſtone, you muſt not ſcape ſo yfaith, one word before you go ſir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pray diſpatch then, I would not for halfe my reue|newes yfaith now, that any gallants ſhould paſſe by in the meane time, and finde me in your companies, nay as quicke as you can ſir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: You did not take away maiſter Bowcers cloake ●other morning, pawnd it to me and borrowed fiue pound vppon't;

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: 'Twas not you neither that finely cheated my little Nouice at maiſter Primeroes houſe, of a Diamond and Saphire, and ſwore they were counterfet, both glaſſe, meere glaſſe as you were a right gentleman;

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Slife, why were we ſtrangers all this while? ſ●oot I perceicue wee are all naturall Brothers? a pox on●s all are we found yfaith?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: A cheater?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A theeſe, a lecher, a bawd and a Broker?

sp.speaker: Cunſt.
sp.p: What meane they to bee ſo merry, Im'e afraid they laugh at vs and make fooles on's.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Puſh, leaue it to me—how now: who would you ſpeake withall?

sp.speaker: Cunſt.
sp.p: Speak withall? haue wee waited all this while, for a ſuſ|pected theefe●

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How? your'r ſcarce awake yet I thinke, looke well, does any appeare like a theefe in this company▪ a|way you ſlaues, you ſtand loytring, when you ſhould looke to the common wealth? you catch knaues apace now, do you not? they may walke by your noſe, your as kalls?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Sweete Maiſter Goldſtone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You lackt ſpirit in your company, till I came among you▪ here ●ee ●iue on's, lets but glew together, why now the world ſhall not come betweene vs.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: If we be true among our ſelues.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why true; we cannot lack to be rich; for we cannot lack riches, nor can our wenches want, nor we want wenches.

sp.speaker: Prl.
sp.p: Let me alone to furniſh you with them.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And me.

lg.l: Theres one care paſt: and as for the Knights daughter,
Our chiefeſt buſineſſe, and leaſt thought vpon.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Thats true ifaith.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: How ſhall we agree for her.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: With as much eaſe as for the reſt: to morrow brings the night, lets all appeare in the beſt ſhape we may; troth is, we haue need on't, and when amongſt vs fiue ſhe makes election, as one ſhe ſhall chooſe.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: True, ſhe cannot chooſe.

lg.l: That one ſo fortunate amongſt vs fiue,
Shall beare himſelfe more portly, liue regarded,
Keepe houſe, and be a countenance to the reſt.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Admirall.

lg.l: For inſtance, put caſe your ſelfe after ſome robbery done
Were purſu'de hardly; why there were your ſhelter,
You know your Sanctuary: nay ſay you were taken,
His letter to the Iuſtice will ſtrik't dead,
'Tis policie to receiue one for the head.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Lets hug thee Goldſtone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What haue I begot?

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I muſt plot for you all, it likes me rarely.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Prethee what iſt ſir?

lg.l: 'Twould ſtrike Fitſgraue pale,
And make the other Suiters appeare blanckes.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: For our vnited miſteries.

lg.l: What if we fiu: preſented our full ſhapes
In a Strange-gallant, and conceited maske?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: In a maske, your thoughts and mine w●te● wins.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: So the deuice were ſubtle nothing like it.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Some Post muſt 〈◊〉〈◊〉▪

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Poet? youle take the direct l●ne to haue vs ſta'gde? why what lacks Bowſer, are you too well, too ſafe, an abſolute ſcholler, eaſie to be wrought, ●o danger in the operation.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: But haue you ſo much intereſt▪

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: What in Bowſer? why my leaſt woo● com●●●●● him:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Then no man fitte●.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: And there's Maiſter Frip too, 〈…〉sh vs of ma●king ſ●i●e〈…〉●●ow.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Vpon ſufficient pawne I thinke I can ſir●

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Pawne? I●we, here take my ●●aine●pa w●es among bro|thers? we ſhall thriue? but wee muſt ſtill expect one ●ongue in fiue, and thinke vs happy too.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Laſt man we ſpoke on, Maiſter Bowſer.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Little maiſter Bowſer, ſweete maiſter Bowſer welcome ifaith?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Are your fathers dead▪ gentlemen, y'are ſo m●rry.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: By my troth a good ieſt, did not I co●●●nd his wit to you gentlemen, harke ●●rm Rafe Bowſer, co●●● Bowſer ifaith? thers a kind of portion in towne, a girle of 15 hundred, whom we al powrefully affect, and determine to preſent our parts to her in a Maske.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: In a Maske!

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Right ſir, now a little of thy braine for a deuice to pre|ſent vs firme, which wee ſhall neuer bee able to do our ſelues thou knowſt that; and with a kind of ſpeech wherein thou mayſt expreſſe what gallants are▪ brauely;

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Puh, how can I expreſſe em otherwiſe but brauely: now for a Mercury and al were fitted.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Could not a boy ſupply it?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Why none better.

lg.l: I haue a boy ſhal put down al the Mercuries ith towne,
A will play a Mercury naturally, at his fingers end ifaith.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Why then wee are ſuted; for torch-bearers and ſheeld|boies, theſe are alwaies the writers properties; y'are not troub|led with them.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Come my little Bowſer; do't finely now, to the life.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: I warrant you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Hiſt; giue me a little touch aboue the 〈◊〉 and you can poſſible, for I meane to preſent this chaine of pearle to her.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Now I know that let me a●o●e to fit you.

div.head: ACT. 5.

sp.speaker: I. Cur.
sp.p: Come forth you ●●ry priuate—why ſpring ſtrumpet haue we found your cloſſe. haunts, your priuate watchtowers, and your 〈…〉till meanes.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: 2. Curt▪
sp.p: You can ſteale ſecretly hether, you miſticall queane you, at twylight, 〈…〉 you haue a priviledge from your hat forſooth, to walke without a man, and no ſuſpition, But 〈…〉 gentlewomen that goe in Ti●es Haue no ſuch liberty we cannot do thus▪ Cuſtome grants that to you thats ſhame in vs.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Haue you donne yet?

sp.speaker: ●. Cur.
sp.p: You broke the backe of one husband already & nowth' others dead with griefe at ſea, with your ſecret expences, cloſe ●●elths cunning filches, and continued banquets in cor|ners; then forſooth you muſt haue your milke-baths to white you, your ●oſe-leaues to ſweeten you, your beane-floure bags, to ſleeke you, and make you ſoft, ſmoothe, & delicate, for laſci|uious entertainement.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So, and you thinke all this while you dance like a theeſe in a ●●ſt y'are ſafe, no body can finde you; pray were not you a P●lmo●gers daughter at firſt, that runne away with a new Courtiar for the loue of Gentlewomens clothes, and bought the faſhion at a deere rate, with the loſſe of your name & cre|dit, why what are all of you, but ruſticall inſides, and citty fleſh, the bloud of yeom●n, and the b●m of gentlewomen—

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: What ſhall wee ſuffer a changeable forepart to out|tongue vs, take that.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Murder, murder—

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p:
How now? why Ladies, a retreate, come, you haue ſhowne your ſpirits ſufficiently, y are all land captaines, and ſo they ſhall finde that come in your quarters, but haue you the law free now to fight and ſcrath among your ſelues and let your
Gallants run away with vs.

sp.speaker: 1. Curti.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: Sweete maiſter Bowſer.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Another?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Why then I perceiue you know nothing: why they are in the way of marriage:
A knights daughter here in towne makes her election among em this night.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: This night?

sp.speaker: Fitſg.
sp.p: This very night, and they all preſent themſelues in a maske before her, know you not this?

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: O traitor Maiſter Goldſtone.

sp.speaker: 3. Cur.
sp.p: Periurde Maiſter Tayl●eer

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Without ſoule?

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: She will chaſe him.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: You haue more cauſe to ioyne, and play the grounds of friendſhip mongſt your ſelues, then raſhly run diuiſional could tell you a meanes to pleaſure you:
Good maiſter Bowſer.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: But that y'are women and are hardly ſecret.
We vow it ſeriouſly?

lg.l: You ſhould be all there in preſence▪
See all, heare all, and yet not they percieue you.

sp.p: So that—

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: Sweete maiſter Bowſer,—I

lg.l: I can ſtand you in ſtead,
For I frame the deuice,—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: If euer—

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Will you do't—harke you—
Content.
And ile make one.

lg.l: And I another,
Weele marre the match,
When that good newes came of my husbands death,
Goldſtone promiſt me marriage.
and Sweare to me.

sp.p: Ile bring his oths in queſtion▪
So will●:

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Agree among your ſelues, for ſhame.
Are we reſolude?
In this who would not faine,
Friends all for my part,
Heer's my lip for thine▪
Round let it go,
All wrath thus quencht,
And I conclude it ſo.

sp.speaker: Prip.
sp.p: How all euents ſtrike euen with my wiſhes, Their owne inuention damnes them,—now Gentlemen? ſtands your aſſiſtance firme?

lg.l: Why 'tis our owne caſe,
Ime ſorry you ſhould doubt.

sp.speaker: 2. Gal.
sp.p: Weele furniſh you?
Are theſe our Gallants?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Are our Gallants theſe?

sp.speaker: Pay●●.
sp.p: Heere be fiue ſhields sir?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Finiſht already, thats well? Ile ſee thy maiſter ſhortly▪

sp.speaker: P●i●.
sp.p: Ime ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.p: Prithee lets ſee maiſter Fitſgraue,

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: I haue blaz'd them,

lg.l: Whats this;
Fooh, you ſhould be a gallant too, for you'r no vniuerſity Schol|ler?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Looke this is Purſuit:, the deuice, a purſe wide open, and the mouth downeward. The wood, Alienis ●ee●●r●●●●nis.
Whats that?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: One that liues out of other mens pockets,

sp.speaker: Pya
sp.p: Thats right?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Heer's Goldſtones three ſiluer dice,
They run hye, two ſincks and a quater?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: They'r hye men fit for his purpoſes—The word,

sp.speaker: 2. Gal.
sp.p: Nay he will cheat his owne brother, nay his owne fa|ther ifaith?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: So much the word imports—Maiſter Primero,
Pox what ſaies he now?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: The deuice, an vnuallued pearle, hid in a caue. The word, Occulos vendit honores,
Whats that▪

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: One that ſells maidenheads by whole-ſale;
Excellently proper?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Maiſter Frip?
That pythagoricall raskall, in a gentlemans ſuite to day, in a knights to morrow:

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: The deuiſe for him; a Cuckow ſitting on a tree? The word, Enauis ex a●ib●s; one bird made of many; for you know as the Sparrow hatches the Cuckow, ſo the Gentleman fethers the Broker?
Let me admire thee, maiſter Fitſgraue?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: They will ſcorne gentlemen: and to aſſiſt them the bet|ter, Purſnets boy that little pretious pick-pocket, has a com|pend ous ſpeech in lattin, and like a Mercury preſents their their diſpoſitions more liberally:
Neuer were poore gallants ſo abuſed?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.

lg.l: Hang 'em, their counterfets, no honeſt ſpirit will pitty 'em▪
This is my Crowne,
So good men ſmile I dread no raskalls frowne.

sp.p: Away, beſtow your ſelues ſecretly, ore'head, this is the place appointed for the rehearſall, to practiſe their behauiours.
We are vaniſht.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Maiſter Bowcer,

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Welſaid yfaith, off with your cloakes gallants, let's fall roundly to our buſines:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Is the boy perfect?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: That's my credit ſir, I warrant you?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: If our little Mercury ſhould bee out, wee ſhould ſcarce be knowne what we are▪

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: I haue tooke a courſe for that, feare it not ſir; looke you firſt heere be your Sheilds:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I Where be our Sheilds?

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: which is mine?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Which is mine maiſter Bowcer? this?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: I pray be contained a little gentlemen, they'l come all time ynough to you, I warrant:

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: This Frip is growne ſo violent;

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Yours to begin withall ſir?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Latroni? why Sheerſe of the Sheere.

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Ifaith? and I haue ſh●●uen ſome ſheeres in my daies.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Now gentlemen are you ſatsfied and pleaſd?
Neue: more amply▪

lg.l: Amongſt vs now falls that deſired lot,
For we ſhall blaſt fiue riualls with one plot.

div.stage: Enter the Virgin betweene two antient gentlemen.

lg.l: Graue gentlemen, in whoſe approued boſomes,
My deceaſt father did repoſe much faith
Your deerely welcome: pray ſit, command muſick,
See nothing want to beautifie this night,
That holds my election in her peacefull armes,
Feaſts, Muſick, Hymnes, thoſe ſweete celeſtiall ſwarmes.

sp.p: May you be bleſt in this election.
That content, may meete perfection.

lg.head: Himne.
lg.l: Sound Lute. Band●ra, Gitterne,
Uioll, Virginalls and Sithron!
Uoices ſpring and lift alowde,
Her name that makes the Muſick proud:
this night perfection,
makes her election:
Follow, follow follow, follow round,
Looke you to that, nay you to that, nay you to that:
Anon, you will be found, anon you will bee found, anon you will bee found.

div.stage: Enter the maske, thus ordered. A torchbearer, a ſheeld-boy, then a masker, ſo throughout, then the ſheeld▪boyes fall at one end, the torchbearers at the other; the maskers ith middle, the torch|bearers are the fiue gentlemen: the ſheeld-boies the wh●res in boies apparrel: the maskers the fiue Gallants, they bow to her ſhe riſes and ſhewes the like, they dance but firſt deliuer the ſheeldes vp; ſhee reades.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Alienis ecce crumenis.

sp.speaker: Purſn.
sp.p: Bowes to her.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Fratremque, Patremque.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Bowes to her.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Conſumptio victus.

sp.speaker: Taylbe
sp.p: Bowes to her.

sp.speaker: Kath
sp.p: Occultos vendit honores.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Bowes to her.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: A Cuckow: en anis ex a●ibus.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Bowes to her.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Are you all as the ſpeech and ſhields diſplay you?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Wee ſhall prooue ſo.

div.stage: They going to dance, each vnhaſpes his weapon from his ſid●, and giues em to the torch-bearers. Katherine ſeemes diſ|truſtfull, but then Fiſgraue whiſpers to her and falls backe. At the end of which all making an honor, Frip preſents her with that chaine of Pearle.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: The very chaine of Pearle was filcht from me.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Hold ſtop th● boy there.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Will none lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How now.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Alas Ime but a broker, 'twas pawnd to me in my ſhop.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha, Fitſgraue?

sp.speaker: Purſ.
sp.p: Peamo●t and the reſt.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Where's Boucer?

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Heere.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Wee are all betraide.

sp.speaker: Fitſ
sp.p: Betrayde▪ ●●●e new forth to betrayde, you haue not ſo much worth: nay ſtruggle not with the net, you are caught for this world.

sp.speaker: 1 Curt.
sp.p: Would we were out.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.

lg.l: 'Twas I fram'd your deuiſe: do you ſee 'twas I;
The whole aſſembly has tooke notice of it,
That you are a gallant cheator,
So much the pawning of my cloake containes▪

sp.p: You a baſe theefe, thinke of Coome-parke and tell me that your a hired Smokſter, heres her letter. In which we are cer|tified that you are a Bawde.
The broker has confeſt it.
So has the boy.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: That boy wilbe hangd, he ſtole the chaine at firſt and has thus long maintainde his maiſters Gallantry.

lg.l: All which we here preſent like captiue ſlaues,
Waiting that doome which their preſumption craues.
How eaſily may our ſuſpectleſſe ſexe,
With faire appeering ſhadowes be deluded:
Deare ſir, you haue the worke ſo well begun,
That tooke from you ſmall glory would be wonne.
Since tis your pleaſure to refer to me,
The doome of theſe; I haue prouided ſo:
They ſhall not altogither looſe their coſt;
See I haue brought wiues for em.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Heart, the ſtrumpets—out, out▪

lg.l: Hauing aſſum'd out of their impudence,
The ſhape of ſheeld-boyes.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: To heapefull confuſion.

lg.l: Rather confine vs to ſtrikt chaſtity▪
A meere impoſſible taske then to wed theſe:
Whom we loth worſe then the f●ul'ſt deſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: O grant em their requeſtes.

lg.l: The doome is paſt,
So ſince your aime was mariage:
Either imbrace it in theſe Curtizans,
Or haue your baſe acts, and fello●●ous liue●
Proclaimd to the indignation of the law,
Which will prouide a publike puniſhment:
As for the boy, and that infectious Bawde,
We put forth thoſe to whipping.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Whipping? you finde not that in the ſtatute to whip ſat|tin.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p:
Since all our ſhifts are diſcouered, as farre as I can ſee tis
our beſt courſe to marry em: weele make them get our liuings.

sp.speaker: Purſ
sp.p: He ſaies true.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You ſee how we are threatened, by my troth wenches be rul'd by me, lets many em and it bee but to plauge em; for when we haue husbands we are vnder couert-baron, and may lie with whom wee liſt; I haue tri'd that in my tother husbands daies.

sp.speaker: All Curt.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: Ile be no more de●erd▪ come, when do you ioyne:

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Theſe forc'd marriages do neuer come to good.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: How can they, when the come to ſuch as you?

lg.l: The often prooue the ruine of great houſes,
Nor Virgin do I in this ſeeke to entice:
All glory to my ſelfe; theſe Gentlemen,
To whome I am bound to loue for kinde aſſiſtance,
Had great affinity in the plot with me.
To them I giue my thankes: my ſelfe to thee,
Thrice worthy Fitſgraue.

sp.speaker: Fitſ.
sp.p: I ha●●ll my wiſhes.

lg.l: And I preſume ther's none but thoſe can frowne,
Whoſe ●nu●s like the ruſhes we tread downe.
